title: State v. Kinard
description: The Court of Appeals affirmed Timothy Kinard's convcition for assault and battery with intent to kill (ABIK).  Kinard appealed on grounds the trial court erred in refusing to charge the jury on the general intent required to convict for ABIK.  However, the court found the trial court's charge regarding malice aforethought properly instructed the jury on the required general intent to kill.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Timothy Terreal Kinard, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Saluda County
Â William P. Keesley, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 4242
Heard April 3, 2007 â€“ Filed May 7, 2007 
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Appellate Defender Kathrine H. Hudgins, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General Shawn L. Reeves, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Donald V. Myers, of Lexington, for Respondent.
			
		
	

SHORT, J.:Â  Timothy Terreal Kinard appeals his conviction for assault and battery with intent to kill (ABIK).Â  Kinard alleges the trial court erred in refusing to charge the jury on the general intent required to convict for ABIK.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
On March 13, 2000, Kinard and his brother, Reginald Davis, entered the home of seventy-six-year-old Hubert Bryan.Â  Kinard claimed he and Davis entered the house through an unlocked door and found Bryan present at his home, but Bryan contended he discovered Davis in his home after he had unlocked the door and entered.Â  Bryan suspected the men entered the home through a window they had pried open.Â  It is undisputed that Bryan drew a handgun and confronted Davis while Kinard remained out of sight.Â  Bryan demanded Davis leave and Davis complied.Â  After Davis left, Kinard came running out of the kitchen, struck Bryan in the head with an iron, and left the home.Â  Bryan sustained an injury to his head which required thirteen stitches, and when he returned from the hospital, he noticed $2,500.00 missing from his home.Â  Kinard and Davis fled to New York, but were later arrested and returned to South Carolina.Â  Â 
 
A Saluda County grand jury indicted Kinard for first degree burglary and assault and battery with intent to kill (ABIK).Â  At trial, the jury convicted Kinard of both charges, and the trial court sentenced him to twenty years imprisonment for burglary and fifteen years imprisonment for ABIK to be served concurrently.[1]Â  Â Kinard appeals.[2]
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œIn criminal cases, the appellate court sits to review errors of law only.â€ Â State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 5, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001).Â  â€œAn appellate court will not reverse the trial judgeâ€™s decision regarding jury charges absent an abuse of discretion.â€Â  State v. Santiago, 370 S.C. 153, 159, 634 S.E.2d 23, 26 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  Generally, the trial court is required to charge only the current and correct law of South Carolina.Â  Sheppard v. State, 357 S.C. 646, 665, 594 S.E.2d 462, 472 (2004). Â Â A charge to the jury is correct if it contains the correct definition of the law when read as a whole.Â  Id. at 665, 594 S.E.2d at 472-73.Â  
 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Kinard contends the trial court erred in refusing to charge the jury on the general intent required to convict for ABIK.Â  We disagree.
ABIK is defined as an unlawful act of a violent nature to the person of another with malice aforethought, either express or implied.Â  State v. Wilds, 355 S.C. 269, 275, 584 S.E.2d 138, 141 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Murder is the killing of a person with malice aforethought, either express or implied.Â  Id.  
With the exception of the death of the victim, each and every element of murder must be proven beyond a reasonable doubt in order for a jury to convict a defendant of ABIK.Â  Id.Â  
 
â€œMalice aforethoughtâ€ is defined as â€œthe requisite mental state for common-law murderâ€ and it utilizes four possible mental states to encompass both specific and general intent to commit the crime.Â  Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary 969 (7th ed. 1999).Â  These four possibilities are intent to kill, intent to inflict grievous bodily harm, extremely reckless indifference to the value of human life (abandoned and malignant heart), and intent to commit a felony (felony murder rule).[3]Â  Id.Â  â€œGeneral intentâ€ is defined as â€œthe state of mind required for the commission of certain common law crimes not requiring specific intentâ€ and it â€œusually takes the form of recklessness . . . or negligence.â€Â  Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary 813 (7th ed. 1999).Â  Â 
Clearly, the above definitions illustrate that malice aforethought encompasses both the specific and general intent to commit murder.Â  As ABIK encompasses each of the required elements of murder except for the death of the victim, it is axiomatic that malice aforethought be the mental state required to commit ABIK.Â  Further, the South Carolina Supreme Court has stated â€œthe required mental state for ABIK, like murder, is malice aforethought.â€Â  State v. Fennell, 340 S.C. 266, 275, 531 S.E.2d 512, 517 (2000).Â  
 

	In this matter the trial court instructed the jury thusly:
	
		Assault and battery with intent to kill has 4 elements.Â  Itâ€™s an unlawful act of violent injury to the person of another accompanied with malice aforethought. â€¦Malice is an essential element of assault and battery with intent to kill.Â  The malice must be aforethought.Â  Thought of just before and at the time the blow was struck. â€¦ 
		
		So what do we mean by malice?Â  Malice imports wickedness, and it excludes any just cause or legal excuse.Â  Malice springs from depravity, from a depraved spirit, from a heart devoid of social duty and fatally bent on mischief.Â  It does not necessarily import ill will towards the specific person who is injured, but rather it signifies a general malignancy towards and recklessness for the life and safety of another or a condition of the mind that shows a heart devoid of social duty and fatally bent on mischief.Â  There has to be a combination between this evil intent existing aforethought, just before and at the commission of the battery, and the act producing the battery. . . .
		Now obviously, folks, malice is a state of mind.Â  The State has to prove to you that the element of malice existed by either direct evidence or circumstantial evidence or a combination of both.
	

In its charge, the court went on to explain that the jury could infer malice from the use of a deadly weapon and explained the difference between ABIK and assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature (ABHAN).Â  The court summed up the instructions and noted ABHAN, unlike ABIK, did not require malice aforethought.Â 
 
At trial, defense counsel relied on State v. Foust, 325 S.C. 12, 479 S.E.2d 50 (1996), in objecting to this instruction.Â  In Foust, the Supreme Court noted numerous prior cases which required intent to kill accompanied with malice in order to convict for ABIK.Â  Id. at 15, 479 S.E.2d at 51.Â  The Court acknowledged the requirement of â€œsomeâ€ intent, but clearly stated a specific intent to kill was not necessary.Â  Id.Â  The court held â€œit is sufficient if there is shown some general intent, such as that heretofore applied in cases of murder in this state,â€ and â€œaccordingly, . . . in charging juries the law of ABIK, South Carolina trial judges should give a standard â€˜intentâ€™ charge . . . .â€Â  Id. at 15-16, 479 S.E.2d at 51-52.Â  Defense counsel interpreted this holding to require a specific instruction regarding general intent to kill.Â  Defense counsel argued you could not convict someone of ABIK if you had malice but not intent to kill or if you had intent to kill without malice.Â  However, when counsel was asked the difference between a general intent to kill and malice aforethought, he replied â€œI donâ€™t know.â€Â Â 
 
While we are mindful of previous opinions from the appellate courts of this state which have treated intent to kill and malice as separate requirements, we, much like both parties and the trial judge below, fail to discern any significant difference between general intent to kill and malice aforethought as they pertain to ABIK.Â  Since the definition of malice aforethought encompasses general intent to kill, we find it difficult to reconcile a manner in which one could find malice aforethought and yet not find general intent to kill.Â  Further, we read the Foust opinion as the elimination of this artificial distinction.Â  In stating that some general intent such as that heretofore applied in murder cases in this state was sufficient to prove ABIK, the Foust court was establishing malice aforethought as the necessary general intent.Â  Since malice aforethought undoubtedly has been established as the intent required in murder cases, we necessarily arrive at the above conclusion.Â  Moreover, our state Supreme Court reaffirmed malice aforethought as the required mental state for ABIK in an opinion decided four years subsequent to Foust.Â  Fennell, 340 S.C. at 275, 531 S.E.2d at 517.Â  Accordingly, we find the trial courtâ€™s jury instruction, which properly charged the jury regarding malice aforethought, to be without error.Â  The jury was given a proper â€œintentâ€ charge.
CONCLUSION
We find no error in the trial courtâ€™s jury instruction.Â  Based on the foregoing, Kinardâ€™s conviction is
AFFIRMED.
KITTREDGE, J., concurs.
ANDERSON, J., concurs in result only.
ANDERSON, J.: (concurring in result only) Because I disagree with the reasoning and analysis of the majority, but vote to affirm the learned circuit judge, I concur in result only.

[1] Kinard does not appeal his conviction for first degree burglary.
[2] Pursuant to Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967), Kinardâ€™s appellate counsel filed a brief along with a petition to be relieved, stating his examination of the record indicated the appeal was without merit.Â  Kinard filed a separate pro se response. Following our Anders review, this court ordered the parties to brief the following issue:

  Whether the circuit court judge erred in not charging the jury on general intent for assault and battery with intent to kill?

  This issue is now our sole appellate consideration.
[3] We note the South Carolina Supreme Court has found the Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary definition of â€œmalice aforethoughtâ€ does not vary in a meaningful way from a proper jury instruction.Â  State v. Harris, 340 S.C. 59, 64, 530 S.E.2d 626, 628 (2000).

title: Williamson v. Middleton
description: Williamson appeals from the trial judge's award of attorneys' fees to Middleton.  Williamson argues that Middleton is not entitled to attorneys' fees,  or in the alternative, that the criteria for awarding attorneys' fees were not met in this case.  In an en banc opinion, a majority of the court affirms the award.
text:
Williamson v. Middleton


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Dan F. Williamson and Dan F. Williamson and Company, Appellants,
				v.
				Alfred C. Middleton, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal from Greenville County
Â C. Victor Pyle, Jr., Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 4243
Heard November 8, 2006 â€“ Filed May 7, 2007Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Desa A. Ballard, of W. Columbia, for Appellants.
				James C. Parham, Patricia S. Revenhorst, and Wallace K. Lightsey, for Respondents.
			
		
	

HEARN, C.J.: Dan F. Williamson and Dan F. Williamson and Company (collectively, â€œWilliamsonâ€) appeal from the trial judgeâ€™s award of attorneysâ€™ fees to Alfred C. Middleton.Â  Williamson argues that Middleton is not entitled to attorneysâ€™ fees, or in the alternative, that the criteria for awarding attorneysâ€™ fees were not met in this case.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
Prior to this litigation, Middleton worked for a number of years as a commissioned salesman for Williamson. When Middleton quit working for Williamson, he was due a commission for having sold pallets to one of Williamsonâ€™s customers.Â  Middleton and Williamson disagreed as to the amount of commission due to Middleton, and Williamson never paid Middleton any commission, even though it eventually admitted owing him $906.62.Â  
 
Middleton left his employment with Williamson to work for Peninsula Plastics, Inc., one of Williamsonâ€™s pallet suppliers.Â  While at his new job, Middleton continued to seek the commission Williamson owed him to no avail, and in the spring of 2001, he hired Mr. James C. Parham, a partner with the Wyche Burgess law firm.Â  Middleton and Parham were personal friends who had met years before when Middleton owned a sporting goods store that Parham frequently visited.Â  Â Â 
On behalf of Middleton, Parham wrote to Williamson inquiring about the commission due.Â  When he received no response, Parham spoke with Williamsonâ€™s attorney, Bill Jordan, informing him that a complaint had already been drafted and that Middleton was ready to sue to recover the unpaid commission.Â  Jordan requested that Middleton refrain from acting on the drafted complaint until Jordan could speak with his client.Â  Parham agreed, and two days later, Jordan filed a complaint on behalf of Williamson against Middleton, alleging causes of action for fraud, constructive fraud, breach of fiduciary duty, and violation of the South Carolina Unfair Trade Practices Act. Middleton filed an answer, denying the allegations and counterclaiming for commissions owed and sanctions under the South Carolina Frivolous Proceedings Act.Â  Middleton also requested attorneysâ€™ fees. Â Upon the initiation of litigation, Patricia Ravenhorst, an associate with the Wyche Burgess firm, assisted Parham in representing Middleton.
While preparing for trial, Middleton had an extraordinarily difficult time collecting responses to its requests for discovery.Â  In Middletonâ€™s first set of interrogatories for Williamson, Middleton asked that Williamson â€œstate with particularity the facts alleged by [Williamson] to form the basis of the first, second, third, fourth, fifth, and sixth causes of action.â€ Williamson provided no alleged facts and instead responded with a mere promise to â€œsupplement[] after further discovery and investigation.â€Â  A verbatim response was provided to Middletonâ€™s request for a statement of all damages sustained by Williamson. After receiving these unhelpful responses, Middletonâ€™s attorneys initiated several phone conversations and wrote a number of letters imploring Williamson to respond to their requests.Â Â  Â 
While Middleton waited for discovery responses during the ensuing months, Williamson filed a motion in October of 2001 seeking to amend its pleadings to add Peninsula Plastics and Middletonâ€™s supervisor at Peninsula Plastics as defendants and to add three more causes of action.Â  When the hearing on Williamsonâ€™s motion was just days away, it finally supplemented its responses to Middletonâ€™s discovery requests.Â  On November 17, 2001, Judge Henry Floyd denied Williamsonâ€™s motion to amend, finding it was not well founded, was not required by justice, and would be prejudicial to Middleton.Â  Less than one month later, Williamson filed a separate lawsuit against Middleton; this suit also named Peninsula Plastics and Middletonâ€™s supervisor as parties and included the very causes of action Williamson attempted to append to the initial complaint against Middleton.Â  Only after Middleton moved to dismiss this new lawsuit and sought attorneysâ€™ fees did Williamson voluntarily dismiss this second complaint.
 
In addition to Williamsonâ€™s race to the courthouse to be the first to file, its uncooperativeness when responding to discovery, and its attempt to circumvent Judge Floydâ€™s order, Williamson also cancelled depositions and mediation several times.Â  In at least one instance, the cancellation was communicated so late that Middleton and both of his attorneys were already at the mediatorâ€™s office when Williamsonâ€™s attorney called to cancel.Â  Approximately one month prior to trial, Williamsonâ€™s attorney moved to be relieved as counsel, and Williamson hired its current counsel. 
 
Of Williamsonâ€™s claims against Middleton, only its cause of action for breach of fiduciary duty went to the jury.Â  The jury returned a verdict in favor of Middleton on that cause of action, and it also found in favor of Middleton on his counterclaim for unpaid commissions, awarding him $906.62 in actual damages.Â 
 
The trial judge, Judge Pyle, found Middleton was entitled to attorneysâ€™ fees, but he asked the parties to attempt to determine the amount of attorneysâ€™ fees amongst themselves.Â  In the event the parties could not agree to an amount, Judge Pyle explained he would set the amount for them.Â  The parties could not come to a consensus on the amount of attorneysâ€™ fees, and Middleton petitioned the court for assistance.Â  A hearing was held before Judge Miller, who awarded Middleton $35,000 in attorneysâ€™ fees.Â  On appeal, our court reversed this award of attorneysâ€™ fees, finding Judge Pyle retained exclusive jurisdiction over the matter.Â  We therefore reversed Judge Millerâ€™s award and remanded the issue of attorneysâ€™ fees for Judge Pyleâ€™s consideration.Â  See Williamson v. Middleton, 2005-UP-011 (S.C. Ct. App. filed January 11, 2005).
At the hearing before Judge Pyle, Williamson argued Middleton was not entitled to attorneysâ€™ fees because he was not the prevailing party; the bill Middletonâ€™s counsel presented documenting over $100,000 worth of work listed hours spent on claims other than the unpaid commissions claim for which attorneysâ€™ fees are allowed; and the amount of fees Middletonâ€™s counsel requested, $35,000, far exceeded the $906.62 verdict. Williamson also argued Middleton did not actually incur any fees because when Parham was deposed, he admitted there was no written fee agreement between him and Middleton.Â 
 
Judge Pyle found Middleton was entitled to attorneysâ€™ fees because he prevailed in his action against Williamson for unpaid commissions pursuant to section 39-65-20 of the South Carolina Code. Â Judge Pyle found that in light of â€œthe detailed time statements, the affidavits of Middletonâ€™s counsel, and a review of the supporting memorandum and notebook of exhibits presented by Middletonâ€™s counsel, . . . the time and labor were reasonable, not duplicative and were required of Middletonâ€™s counsel in asserting his claim and overcoming the obstructions presented by [Williamson].â€ Judge Pyle also pointed out that although the detailed statements submitted by Middletonâ€™s counsel showed $106,992 in attorneysâ€™ fees, Middleton requested only a fraction of that amount.Â  With regard to contingency of compensation, Judge Pyle acknowledged that Middleton and his attorney had not entered into a formal, written fee agreement, but they relied instead â€œon their long-standing personal relationship and mutual agreement to determine an appropriate fee for services at the conclusion of this matter.â€ Judge Pyle found such an agreement did not preclude attorneysâ€™ fees.Â  Finally, the judge noted that the fees were reasonable despite a verdict of only $906.62 because Williamson forced Middleton to file his counterclaim even though Williamson admitted he owed this amount at trial.Â  Judge Pyle explained: 
 

	Failure to award Middleton reasonable attorneysâ€™ fees and costs incurred in this matter would encourage employers to discourage and obstruct legitimate claims by employees. . . .Â  Employers, such as [Williamson], with significant financial resources should not be permitted to systematically obstruct an employeeâ€™s efforts to recover unpaid commissions or other wages however small the sum might be.Â  Such a result would be especially egregious in the present case considering the fact that [Williamson] admit[s] owing Middleton these unpaid commissions before and during the course of this extended litigation, but consistently refused to pay him anything.

Accordingly, Judge Pyle awarded Middleton $35,000 in attorneysâ€™ fees.Â  Williamson filed a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion, which was denied.Â  This appeal followed.
 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The parties disagree as to the standard of review.Â  During oral argument, Williamson urged us to apply either an equitable standard of review pursuant to Hanahan v. Simpson, 326 S.C. 140, 485 S.E.2d 903 (1997), or an abuse of discretion standard of review pursuant to Russell v. Wachovia, 370 S.C. 5, 633 S.E.2d 722 (2006).[2]Â Â  In either event, Williamson argued we should not review the trial judgeâ€™s decision under an â€œany evidenceâ€ standard.Â  Middleton agrees that an abuse of discretion standard should be applied, but that under such standard, an appellate court will affirm the trial judge so long as there is any competent evidence supporting the judgeâ€™s decision.Â  
 
We find the law well settled that the review of attorneyâ€™s fees awarded pursuant to statute is governed by an abuse of discretion standard.Â  See, e.g., Blumberg v. Nealco, 310 S.C. 492, 493, 427 S.E.2d 659, 660 (1993) (finding that a trial judgeâ€™s decision to award attorneyâ€™s fees will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion); Heath v. County of Aiken, 302 S.C. 178, 182, 394 S.E.2d 709, 711 (1990) (holding that when attorneyâ€™s fees are awarded pursuant to section 15-77-300 of the South Carolina Code, the appellate court reviews the award under an abuse of discretion standard); Video Gaming Consultants, Inc. v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Revenue, 358 S.C. 647, 649-52, 595 S.E.2d 890, 891 (Ct. App. 2004) (â€œOn appeal, the trial courtâ€™s decision regarding attorneyâ€™s fees under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-77-300 (Supp. 2003) will not be disturbed absent an abuse of discretion.â€).Â  The law is equally clear that an appellate court will not reverse an award unless it is based on an error of law or is without any evidentiary support. Â See Gooding v. St. Francis Xavier Hosp., 326 S.C. 248, 252, 487 S.E.2d 596, 598 (1997) (â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs when there is an error of law or a factual conclusion which is without evidentiary support.â€); Baron Data Sys. v. Loter, 297 S.C. 382, 384, 377 S.E.2d 296, 296 (1989) (â€œWhere an attorneyâ€™s services and their value are determined by the trier of fact, an appeal will not prevail if the findings of fact are supported by any competent evidence.â€); Fontaine v. Peitz, 291 S.C. 536, 538, 354 S.E.2d 565, 566 (1987) (â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs when the judgeâ€™s ruling is based upon an error of law or when based upon factual conclusion, is without evidentiary support.â€).Â  Accordingly, we will affirm the trial judgeâ€™s award of $35,000 in attorneysâ€™ fees if any competent evidence exists to support the award.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Williamson first argues Middleton is not entitled to attorneysâ€™ fees because he does not meet the requirements of section 39-65-30 of the South Carolina Code.Â  Specifically, Williamson points out that this statute only applies to sales representatives who seek to recover commissions on â€œwholesaleâ€ sales, and the sale Middleton seeks commissions from was made to the ultimate consumer.Â  We find this issue is not preserved for our review.
Initially, we note that Williamsonâ€™s arguments to Judge Pyle on this issue are not reflected in the record on appeal.Â  Williamson did not advance this argument at the hearing before Judge Pyle, and although Williamsonâ€™s counsel refers to a memorandum she filed in opposition to Middletonâ€™s request for attorneysâ€™ fees, that memorandum was not included in the record on appeal. Â See Taylor v. Taylor, 294 S.C. 296, 299, 363 S.E.2d 909, 911 (Ct. App. 1987) (â€œThe burden is on the appellant to furnish a sufficient record on appeal from which this court can make an intelligent review.â€).Â  We acknowledge, however, that Judge Pyle addressed the argument in his order awarding attorneysâ€™ fees, suggesting the argument was set forth in Williamsonâ€™s memorandum.Â  In the order, Judge Pyle found Williamsonâ€™s argument that Middleton was not entitled to attorneysâ€™ fees and costs pursuant to section 39-65-30 came too late because during trial, Williamson never objected to the jury instructions referencing section 39-65-30, nor did Williamson challenge Judge Pyleâ€™s initial ruling that Middleton was entitled to attorneysâ€™ fees.Â  Williamson did not seek a reconsideration of these findings by Judge Pyle in its Rule 59(e) motion.Â  
 
In its brief to our court, Williamson argues that â€œ[e]ven though the jury returned a verdict . . . that awarded Middleton $906.62 for unpaid commissions, this recovery was sought on alternate grounds, both pursuant to Â§ 39-56-30 and Â§ 41-10-10.â€Â  In so arguing, Williamson implies the juryâ€™s award was based on a statute other than section 39-56-30.Â  Williamson further contends that its argument on this issue is timely because â€œthe request for attorney fees is predicated on entirely different factors than was the request for commissions.â€Â  From the record before us, there is no indication this specific argument was ever made to the trial judge, either prior to the order awarding attorneysâ€™ fees or in Williamsonâ€™s motion for reconsideration.Â  Thus, the issue is not preserved for review.Â  See Staubes v. City of Folly Beach, 339 S.C. 406, 412, 529 S.E.2d 543, 546 (2000) (â€œIt is well-settled that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial court to be preserved for appellate review.â€); State v. Nelson, 331 S.C. 1, 5 n.6, 501 S.E.2d 716, 718 n.6 (1998) (â€œ[T]he ultimate goal behind preservation of error rules is to insure (sic) that an issue raised on appeal has first been addressed to and ruled on by the trial court.â€).
Next, Williamson argues Middleton did not actually incur any attorneysâ€™ fees.Â  We disagree.
The jury awarded Middleton unpaid commission pursuant to section 39-65-20 of the South Carolina Code.Â  When an employer violates that code section, the employer is liable for â€œattorneyâ€™s fees actually and reasonably incurred by the sales representative in the action and court costs.â€Â  Williamson argues Middleton never incurred attorneysâ€™ fees because he had no obligation to pay Parham.Â  In support of its argument, Williamson focuses on Parhamâ€™s deposition testimony in which he stated:

	[W]e donâ€™t have a fee agreement with Mr. Middleton. Â We talked about this with Mr. Middleton to begin with and we decided that we would try to help him collect the monies due him and at the end of the case, we would talk about a fee.Â  So we donâ€™t have a fee agreement with him.Â  But some day, he might pay us a fee.Â  Right now, he has no obligation at this point if there is no agreement. Â He might feel a moral obligation.Â  And when we talk at the end of the case, he will have the final say.

Williamson argues this statement indicates Middleton had neither a fee agreement with nor an obligation to his attorneys, and accordingly, the holding of Hopkins v. Hopkins, 343 S.C. 301, 540 S.E.2d 454 (2000), precludes attorneysâ€™ fees from being awarded.Â  
 
In Hopkins, the supreme court upheld the family courtâ€™s determination that Husband was not entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees when he was represented at trial by his new wife, an attorney.Â  In so holding, the supreme court not only pointed out there was no fee agreement between Husband and his wife/attorney, but the Hopkins court also stressed there was no â€œindication or testimony that [Husbandâ€™s] wife/attorney intends to collect the fees from [Husband].â€Â  Id. at 307, 540 S.E.2d at 457.Â  
 
Unlike Hopkins, there is evidence in this record to indicate Middletonâ€™s attorneys intended to collect their fee from Middleton.Â  While Parhamâ€™s testimony, excerpted above, could be interpreted to mean Middleton would never be required to pay a fee, it also indicates that â€œat the end of the case, [Middleton and his attorneys] would talk about a fee.â€Â  Judge Pyle adopted this latter interpretation, finding that although there was no â€œformal, written fee agreement in this matter,â€ Middleton and his counsel â€œhave relied on their long-standing personal relationship and mutual agreement to determine an appropriate fee for services at the conclusion of this matter.â€Â  Additionally, Parham testified he was hired by Middleton in the Spring of 2001, and since that time, diligent records were kept detailing the amount of time spent on the case.Â  Furthermore, while Parham described Middleton as his â€œgood friend,â€ such a relationship is not akin to the matrimonial bond found in Hopkins from which gratuitous representation would be expected.Â  It would be even less reasonable to believe Ravenhorst, Middletonâ€™s second-chair attorney who had no prior relationship with Middleton, would have volunteered her time without an expectation of being paid.
 
Although we recognize there was no formal fee agreement between Middleton and his attorneys, the lack of such an agreement does not preclude an attorney from collecting fees.Â  See Singleton v. Collins, 251 S.C. 208, 210-11, 161 S.E.2d 246, 247 (1968) (â€œAn attorney has a right to be paid for professional services rendered, and where there is no express contract, the law will imply one.â€).Â  Although the Singleton case is procedurally different from the case at hand, its determination regarding attorneyâ€™s fees is instructive.Â  In Singleton, an attorney filed an action to collect fees after rendering services to a client in a domestic relations action.Â  Despite the lack of a formal contract, the trial court implied a contract and determined the amount of attorneyâ€™s fees owed.Â  Our supreme court upheld the trial courtâ€™s decision, noting: â€œWhether the services were rendered, and their value, are matters of fact to be decided . . . by the court below, and no appeal lies therefrom if the findings of fact are supported by any competent evidence.â€Â  Id. at 211, 161 S.E.2d at 247.
Although Singleton involves the collection of attorneyâ€™s fees from a client rather than an opposing party, it illustrates that the lack of a formal agreement is not fatal to an attorneyâ€™s claim for fees.Â  Here, the trial judge was not precluded from awarding attorneysâ€™ fees simply because Middleton and his attorneys lacked a written agreement.Â  Rather, so long as there was evidence Middletonâ€™s attorneys intended to collect a fee, the trial judge had discretion to award the fee.Â  Not only did Judge Pyle find there was such evidence, but Judge Miller, whose ruling was reversed for lack of subject matter jurisdiction, found an informal agreement existed as well.Â  Because there is competent evidence in the record to support the findings of these two outstanding trial judges, we find no abuse in discretion.
In addition to its argument that Middleton did not incur attorneysâ€™ fees, Williamson also argues Middleton failed to prove the other elements necessary to recover fees.Â  We disagree.
When awarding attorneyâ€™s fees, the trial court must consider the following six factors: (1) the nature, extent, and difficulty of the legal services rendered; (2) the time and labor necessarily devoted to the case; (3) the professional standing of counsel; (4) the contingency of compensation; (5) the fee customarily charged in the locality for similar legal services; and (6) the beneficial results obtained.Â  Baron Data Sys, Inc., v. Loter, 297 S.C. at 384-85, 377 S.E.2d at 297.Â  â€œWhere an attorneyâ€™s services and their value are determined by the trier of fact, an appeal will not prevail if the findings of fact are supported by any competent evidence.â€Â  Id. at 384, 377 S.E.2d at 296 (emphasis added).Â  Here, Judge Pyle made specific findings on each of the six elements, and there is evidence in the record supporting those findings.Â  
 
Finally, Williamson argues that even if Middleton was entitled to attorneysâ€™ fees, the amount of attorneysâ€™ fees awarded was unreasonable in light of the meager verdict Middleton received.Â  However, â€œthere is no requirement that attorneyâ€™s fees be less than or comparable to a partyâ€™s monetary judgment.â€Â  Taylor v. Medenica, 331 S.C. 575, 580, 503 S.E.2d 458, 461 (1998).Â  Furthermore, although a $35,000 attorneysâ€™ fee may initially seem high for a cause of action for unpaid commissions, especially when the action resulted in a $906.62 verdict, under the peculiar circumstances of this case, there was evidence in the record supporting the trial judgeâ€™s finding that $35,000 was a reasonable amount to award.Â

Speed, 326 S.C. 289, 308, 486 S.E.2d 750, 760 (1997) (â€œ[A]n award for attorneyâ€™s fees will be affirmed so long as sufficient evidence in the record supports each factor.â€); McMaster v. Strickland, 322 S.C. 451, 455, 472 S.E.2d 623, 626 (1996) (affirming special refereeâ€™s award of attorneyâ€™s fees notwithstanding his failure to make specific findings about each of the six Blumberg factors because the record contained ample support for each of the six factors).
Encapsulating the facts of this case and the law, I conclude that the amount of the award of the attorneyâ€™s fee is NOT supported by the evidentiary record.Â  Further, the amount of the award is unreasonable and unjustified.Â  In reviewing the Baron Data factors and juxtaposing the evidentiary record to the law extant, I come to the ineluctable conclusion that the amount of the award of attorneyâ€™s fees far exceeds any notion of reasonableness.Â Â  
 
CONCLUSION
I hold that in South Carolina under section 39-65-30 of the South Carolina Code an attorneyâ€™s fee must be actually incurred before the court can award an attorneyâ€™s fee.Â  Additionally, I determine that the amount of the award of the attorneyâ€™s fee in the case sub judice is unreasonable under the facts and law.Â  Accordingly, I VOTE to REVERSE the award of fees because no attorneyâ€™s fee was incurred in this case.Â  Alternatively, even if an award of an attorneyâ€™s fee is appropriate under the statute, I VOTE to REMAND for further consideration as to a reasonable amount.Â  
 
BEATTY, J., dissenting in a separate opinion:Â  I respectfully dissent.Â  Rule 219 SCACR states that en banc consideration is not favored and ordinarily will not be granted except:Â  (1) when consideration by the full court is necessary to secure or maintain uniformity of its decisions; or (2) when the proceeding involves a question of exceptional importance.Â  The case sub judice does not adhere to either exception.Â  Therefore, I dissent.
SHORT, J., (dissenting in a separate opinion):Â  I respectfully dissent.Â  I join in Judge Andersonâ€™s dissent in finding no attorney fee agreement existed between Middleton and his attorney.Â Â  However, having found the absence of a fee agreement, I do not find it necessary to address the reasonableness of the attorneyâ€™s fee in this matter.
CURETON, A.J.: (Dissenting in separate opinion): I too agree with Judge Andersonâ€™s dissent to the extent it finds no attorney fee agreement was ever entered into between Middleton and his attorney.Â  I also agree with Judge Short that having concluded there was no fee agreement, there is no need to address the reasonableness of the attorney fee award.

[1] In a split decision, a three-judge panel from this court reversed the award.Â  See Williamson v. Middleton, Op. No. 4135 (S.C. Ct. App. filed July 10, 2006) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 27 at 47).Â  We granted en banc review, which has again resulted in a divided court.Â  Five panel members vote to affirm the award, and four panel members vote to reverse it.Â  This division results in an affirmance of the trial judgeâ€™s award of attorneysâ€™ fees.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 14-8-90 (Supp. 2006) (requiring a concurrence of six of the judges when reversing the judgment below). 
 
[2] The Hanahan case to which Williamson cites sets forth an equitable standard of review when attorneyâ€™s fees are awarded as a sanction for filing a frivolous proceeding.Â  Under the Frivolous Proceedings Act, a judge, sitting without a jury, determines whether the party against whom attorneyâ€™s fees are sought initiated litigation in bad faith or with no reasonable cause.Â  This is an equitable determination, and therefore, an equitable standard of review is used when considering the trial judgeâ€™s award of fees.Â  See Brown v. State Farm Mutual Ins. Co., 275 S.C. 276, 269 S.E.2d 769 (1980).Â  Unlike a fee awarded as a sanction under the Frivolous Proceedings Act, the attorneyâ€™s fee awarded to Middleton was based on the juryâ€™s award of commissions pursuant to section 39-56-20 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2006).Â  A party who violates section 39-56-20 is liable for â€œattorneyâ€™s fees actually and reasonably incurred by the sales representative in the action . . . .â€ S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 39-56-30 (Supp. 2006).Â  Thus, the award of attorneyâ€™s fees was based upon the juryâ€™s finding for Middleton and was not an equitable determination by the trial judge.Â

title: State v. Gentile
description: Appellant appeals his conviction for trafficking in cocaine and possession with intent to distribute cocaine within proximity of a school.  He contends the circuit court judge erred in denying his motion to suppress the drug evidence on the ground the search warrant was not supported by probable cause.
text:
PREHEARING REPORT


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Omar Sharitt Gentile, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Charleston County
Thomas A. Russo, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 4244
Submitted April 2, 2007 â€“ Filed May 8, 2007
REVERSED


	
		
			
				Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III, Commission on Indigent Defense, of Appellate Defense.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General Shawn L. Reeves, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Ralph E. Hoisington, of Charleston, for Respondent.
			
		
	

BEATTY, J.:Â  A circuit court judge, during a bench trial, convicted Omar Gentile of trafficking in cocaine and possession with intent to distribute cocaine within proximity of a school.Â  Gentile asserts the judge erred in denying his motion to suppress the drug evidence on the ground the search warrant was not supported by probable cause.Â  We reverse.[1]
FACTS
At approximately 9:45 p.m. on July 10, 2004, officers with the narcotics division of the Charleston Police Department forcibly executed a search warrant for Gentileâ€™s residence in Charleston.Â  Pursuant to the search, the officers seized one plastic bag containing 24.34 grams of cocaine and $988 in cash from Gentileâ€™s person.Â  The officers also discovered six plastic bags containing 2.14 grams of cocaine. Â Gentile ultimately admitted that the drugs belonged to him. As a result, a Charleston County grand jury indicted Gentile for trafficking in cocaine and possession with intent to distribute cocaine within proximity of a school.Â  
 
Prior to his bench trial, Gentile filed a written motion to suppress all evidence seized from his residence.Â  In his motion, Gentile argued there was no probable cause to support the issuance of the search warrant.Â  During the trial, the court reviewed the search warrant and accompanying affidavit and heard testimony from the officers involved in the search.Â 
 
The affidavit in support of the search warrant provided in pertinent part:

	Investigators recieved [sic] information of narcotic activity at 23 Cleveland ST Apartment A.Â  Investigators conducted periodic surveillance on 23 Cleveland ST and observed a black male enter the residence.Â  Black male subject was observed leaving the residence.Â  Subject was stopped by narcotic investigators and recovered approximately 4.0 grams of marijuana.Â  Subject made no stops from time of leaving residence until stopped by investigators.Â  Based on above information, there is probable cause to believe narcotics (marijuana) and proceeds from narcotic sales to be stored inside 23 Cleveland ST Apartment A., Charleston, South Carolina.
	

Officer George Bradley, the officer who procured the warrant from the magistrate, testified regarding his affidavit as well as the oral testimony he gave to the magistrate.Â  According to Bradley, the Charleston Police Department received citizen complaints regarding suspected narcotics traffic at Gentileâ€™s residence. Â Bradley testified the citizens claimed to have witnessed heavy foot traffic â€œin and out of the residence, later in the afternoon up until the wee morning hours.â€ Â As a result of these tips, Bradley and Officer Steven Sierko conducted surveillance of the residence.Â  Bradley testified they observed â€œseveral black males entering and leaving the residence, walking in, being in there less than five minutes.â€Â  Bradley alerted officers in a nearby unmarked patrol car regarding one particular visitor.Â  Corporal Andre Jenkins followed the visitorâ€™s vehicle as it left the residence and then conducted a traffic stop for an obstructed license plate.Â  Jenkins arrested the driver of the vehicle after he refused to produce his driverâ€™s license and then engaged in a physical altercation.Â  A search of the driverâ€™s person revealed two bags of marijuana.Â Â Â 
 
After this arrest, Corporal Jenkins contacted Bradley to inform him that he believed there was probable cause for a search warrant based on the officersâ€™ observations regarding the traffic at the residence and the subsequent arrest of one of the visitors. Â Jenkins also testified that he established his belief on the citizen tips regarding the traffic at the residence as well as the complaint of one citizen who claimed she smelled marijuana in the vicinity of the residence. 
 
Based on the citizen tips, his observations during the surveillance, the arrest of one of the visitors, as well as his experience, Bradley believed narcotics transactions were being conducted at Gentileâ€™s residence.Â  Bradley testified he presented this information to the magistrate who ultimately signed the warrant for the search of Gentileâ€™s residence.
At the conclusion of the suppression hearing testimony, Gentileâ€™s counsel reiterated his motion to suppress.Â  He asserted the search warrant was invalid because there was no probable cause.Â  Specifically, he claimed there was no independent verification of what transpired within Gentileâ€™s residence.Â  Instead, counsel averred the citizen complaints, the officersâ€™ observations, and the arrest were a series of unrelated events that did not support a finding of probable cause. Â The judge denied the motion, finding the search warrant was properly issued based on the totality of the circumstances.Â  Although the judge recognized that there was no â€œindication with regards to the reliability of the informant information,â€ he found the officers did not seek a warrant solely on this information.Â  Instead, the judge found significant that the warrant was procured based on the officersâ€™ â€œown investigation, through their own observations . . . which through their experience as narcotics officers for several years have proven to indicate the presence of drug activity.â€ 
 
The judge convicted Gentile of trafficking in cocaine and possession with intent to distribute cocaine within proximity of a school.Â  He sentenced Gentile to twenty-five years imprisonment for the trafficking offense and a concurrent, ten-year sentence for the other offense.Â  Gentile appeals his convictions and sentences. 
 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œIn criminal cases, the appellate court sits to review errors of law only.â€Â  State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 5, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001).Â  We are bound by the trial courtâ€™s factual findings unless they are clearly erroneous. State v. Quattlebaum, 338 S.C. 441, 452, 527 S.E.2d 105, 111 (2000).Â  â€œA deferential standard of review likewise applies in the context of a Fourth Amendment challenge to a trial courtâ€™s fact-driven affirmation of probable cause.â€Â  State v. Thompson, 363 S.C. 192, 199, 609 S.E.2d 556, 560 (Ct. App. 2005).
DISCUSSION
Gentile argues the judge erred in denying his motion to suppress because the search warrant was not supported by probable cause.Â  We agree. 
 
The Fourth Amendment guarantees â€œ[t]he right of the people to be secure . . . [from] unreasonable searches and seizures.â€ U.S. Const. amend. IV. Â â€œIn parallel with the protection of the Fourth Amendment, the South Carolina Constitution also provides a safeguard against unlawful searches and seizures.â€ Â State v. Forrester, 343 S.C. 637, 643, 541 S.E.2d 837, 840 (2001); S.C. Const. art. I, Â§ 10. Â Evidence obtained in violation of the Fourth Amendment is inadmissible in both state and federal court. Forrester, 343 S.C. at 643, 541 S.E.2d at 840.
A magistrate may issue a search warrant only upon a finding of probable cause.Â  State v. Bellamy, 336 S.C. 140, 143, 519 S.E.2d 347, 348 (1999).Â  â€œThis determination requires the magistrate to make a practical, common-sense decision of whether, given the totality of the circumstances set forth in the affidavit, including the veracity and basis of knowledge of persons supplying the information, there is a fair probability that contraband or evidence of a crime will be found in a particular place.â€Â  State v. King, 349 S.C. 142, 150, 561 S.E.2d 640, 644 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  â€œThe affidavit must contain sufficient underlying facts and information upon which the magistrate may make a determination of probable cause.Â  The magistrate should determine probable cause based on all of the information available to the magistrate at the time the warrant was issued.â€Â  State v. Dupree, 354 S.C. 676, 684, 583 S.E.2d 437, 441 (Ct. App. 2003) (citations omitted).
In discussing the specific requirements for issuing a search warrant, our supreme court has explained:

	The General Assembly has imposed stricter requirements than federal law for issuing a search warrant. Both the Fourth Amendment of the United States Constitution and Article I, Â§ 10 of the South Carolina Constitution require an oath or affirmation before probable cause can be found by an officer of the court, and a search warrant issued.Â  U.S. Const. amend. IV; S.C. Const. art. I, Â§Â  10. Â Additionally, the South Carolina Code mandates that a search warrant â€œshall be issued only upon affidavit sworn to before the magistrate, municipal judicial officer, or judge of a court of record . . . .â€Â  S.C. Code Ann.Â  Â§ 17-13-140 (1985). Oral testimony may also be used in this state to supplement search warrant affidavits which are facially insufficient to establish probable cause. 
	See State v. Weston, 329 S.C. 287, 494 S.E.2d 801 (1997). Â However, â€œsworn oral testimony, standing alone, does not satisfy the statute.â€ 
	State v. McKnight, 291 S.C. 110, 352 S.E.2d 471 (1987).

State v. Jones, 342 S.C. 121, 128, 536 S.E.2d 675, 678-79 (2000).
In terms of a courtâ€™s review of the magistrateâ€™s decision, â€œ[t]he duty of the reviewing court is to ensure the issuing magistrate had a substantial basis upon which to conclude that probable cause existed.â€ Â State v. Baccus, 367 S.C. 41, 50, 625 S.E.2d 216, 221 (2006).Â  â€œIn reviewing the validity of a warrant, an appellate court may consider only information brought to the magistrateâ€™s attention.â€Â  State v. Thompson, 363 S.C. 192, 200, 609 S.E.2d 556, 560 (Ct. App. 2005).
Reviewing this case within the above-outlined parameters, we find the affidavit and the supplemental oral testimony were insufficient to provide the magistrate with a substantial basis for which to find probable cause to issue the search warrant for Gentileâ€™s residence.
Although we are cognizant that our decision should be based on the totality of the circumstances, for analytical purposes we find it necessary to separately address each piece of evidence presented to the magistrate.Â 
 
The narcotics officersâ€™ decision to investigate Gentile was precipitated primarily by the receipt of citizen complaints regarding a high volume of traffic at Gentileâ€™s residence.Â  Even though the officers verified the pattern of traffic at Gentileâ€™s residence, this, without additional investigation into the residence, was not sufficient to establish that narcotics activity was taking place.Â  See State v. Hunt, 562 S.E.2d 597, 601-02 (N.C. Ct. App. 2002) (reversing trial courtâ€™s decision denying defendantâ€™s motion to suppress drug evidence and stating â€œ[a]ll that the affidavit offers are complaints from citizens suspicious of drug activity in a nearby house.Â  There is no mention of anyone ever seeing drugs on the premises.Â  The citizens only reported heavy vehicular traffic to the house.Â  The officer verified the traffic.Â  His verification, as the trial court found, was not a conclusion.â€); Bailey v. People, 15 Cal. Rptr. 2d 17, 19-20 (Cal. Ct. App. 1992) (finding information from an anonymous informer and an unidentified citizen regarding heavy foot traffic at defendantâ€™s residence, without investigation, was insufficient to establish probable cause for the issuance of a search warrant; stating â€œâ€˜heavy foot trafficâ€™ does not necessarily engender criminal behavior.Â  True, under certain circumstances, such activity might raise suspicions, or be one indicator of possible narcotics transactions.â€).Â Â Â 
 
Next, we consider the single citizen claim that she smelled marijuana in the vicinity of Gentileâ€™s residence.Â  Initially, we question whether the magistrate was privy to this information.Â  Based on our review of the record, we are unable to find where Bradley, the officer who obtained the warrant, testified regarding this information.Â  Instead, the only reference to this tip was through the testimony of Corporal Jenkins. Â Furthermore, there is no mention in the affidavit regarding this tip.Â  Therefore, it is questionable whether it was communicated to the magistrate.Â  Â Â 
Even if we conclude that Bradley communicated to the magistrate the citizenâ€™s tip, we find it was insufficient to establish probable cause.Â  First, the tip is vague in that there is no indication of how many times the citizen may have smelled marijuana or that she could readily identify that the odor was emanating from Gentileâ€™s residence.Â  Secondly, there was no indication that the citizen was knowledgeable about the smell or marijuana.Â  Significantly, there was no independent verification by the narcotics officers regarding this tip.[2]
Finally, the arrest of one of Gentileâ€™s visitors did not support a finding of probable cause to search the residence.[3]Â  According to the testimony and the affidavit, the officers discovered marijuana in the possession of the driver after he left Gentileâ€™s residence.Â  The officers, however, had no knowledge of whether the driver purchased the marijuana from Gentile.Â  Neither the driver nor his vehicle was searched prior to going to Gentileâ€™s residence.Â  Furthermore, without surveillance within Gentileâ€™s residence, there was no verification that the driver in fact purchased marijuana from Gentile.Â  Additionally, it is important to note that the officersâ€™ search of Gentileâ€™s residence revealed cocaine and not marijuana.
Based on the foregoing, we hold the search warrant was invalid under the totality of the circumstances, and thus, the circuit court judge erred in admitting the drug evidence. Â 
We find support for our decision in the factually similar opinion of People v. Titus, 880 P.2d 148 (Colo. 1994)(en banc).Â  In Titus, the defendant was charged with possession of marijuana with intent to distribute or sell and possession of marijuana.Â  The drug evidence was discovered at Titusâ€™s residence pursuant to the execution of a search warrant.Â  The Colorado Springs Police Department procured the warrant based on the following information:Â  1). a first-time anonymous informant alleged defendant was engaged in selling marijuana at his residence, there was unusual traffic at defendantâ€™s residence, and that she had smelled the odor of burning marijuana coming from the residence; 2). the informant gave police a list of the license plate numbers of those that visited the defendantâ€™s residence; 3). police officersâ€™ verification of the license plate numbers and the traffic at the defendantâ€™s residence; 4). an attempted controlled buy of narcotics from defendant; and 5). the fact that the defendant was self-employed and operated a telephone repair business out of his home.
Prior to trial, the court granted the defendantâ€™s motion to suppress the drug evidence found at his residence on the ground the affidavit underlying the search warrant did not establish probable cause.Â  Id. at 149.Â  The prosecution appealed the decision.Â  On appeal, the Colorado Supreme Court, sitting en banc, affirmed the trial courtâ€™s ruling.Â  Â In reaching this decision the court found â€œthe police had no indication, apart from the anonymous informantâ€™s suspicions and the police informantâ€™s conversation with Titus, that Titus was engaged in criminal activity.â€Â  Id. at 151.Â  In terms of the high volume of traffic at the defendantâ€™s residence, the court stated â€œ[t]he fact that a large number of people visit a residence in a one-month period does not establish that illegal activity is taking place.â€Â  The court also relied on the fact that there was nothing in the affidavit to suggest that â€œany of the [visiting] vehicles belonged to known drug offenders, or were used in the furtherance of any illegal activity.â€Â  Id.Â  Finally, the court rejected the prosecutionâ€™s reliance on the anonymous informantâ€™s claims that she smelled the odor of burned marijuana coming from the defendantâ€™s residence on several occasions.Â  Id. at 152.Â  The court found that â€œ[u]nder no circumstances do [the claims] support the conclusion that Titus was selling marijuana out of his home.â€Â  Id.Â  In reaching this conclusion, the court found significant the fact that:

	[t]he affidavit does not state the circumstances under which the informant smelled the odor of burned marijuana.Â  Nor does it disclose how many times she smelled it.Â  Most importantly, however, it does not disclose when these olfactory experiences took place.Â  There is no indication that the police officer attempted to determine whether the informant had smelled marijuana burning recently, or whether the event was remote in time.

Id. 
As in Titus, we find the warrant to search Gentileâ€™s home was not supported by probable cause.Â  The narcotics officersâ€™ decision to obtain the search warrant was based on citizensâ€™ tips regarding high volume traffic at Gentileâ€™s residence, which was not necessarily indicative of illegal activity at the residence.Â  Additionally, the citizen claim regarding the smell of marijuana in the vicinity of Gentileâ€™s residence was vague and not corroborated by the officersâ€™ surveillance.Â  Finally, as previously discussed, the officersâ€™ arrest of a visitor to Gentileâ€™s residence adds nothing to the probable cause determination.Â  Without more, we find the evidence in the affidavit and the oral testimony was insufficient to support a finding of probable cause.
Accordingly, Gentileâ€™s convictions and sentences are 
 
REVERSED.
HUFF and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  Because the narcotics officers did not verify the citizen tip regarding the odor of marijuana, we find the instant case distinguishable from State v. Ford, 323 S.E.2d 358 (N.C. Ct. App. 1984), a case relied upon by the State at trial and on appeal.Â  In Ford, the defendant was convicted of trafficking in marijuana based on a search of his residence which revealed 10,000 pounds of marijuana.Â  On appeal, Ford challenged the trial courtâ€™s denial of his motion to suppress the drug evidence on the ground the supporting affidavit failed to show sufficient probable cause to justify the issuance of the search warrant.Â  Id. at 361.Â Â  The North Carolina Court of Appeals affirmed the trial courtâ€™s decision, finding that evidence presented to the magistrate regarding unusual traffic at a residence in conjunction with the surveillance officerâ€™s detection of marijuana odors coming from within a mobile home, which was identified as belonging to Ford, was sufficient to constitute probable cause.Â  Id. at 361-62.Â  In the instant case, unlike in Ford, the surveillance officers did not verify the citizenâ€™s vague claim regarding the smell of marijuana.Â  Without further investigation by the narcotics officers, we do not believe the citizenâ€™s general claim was sufficient to establish probable cause.
[3]Â Â  At trial, the State relied on two cases decided by this court for the proposition that an arrest, which yields the presence of narcotics, is sufficient to establish probable cause for the issuance of a search warrant for the location of where the arrestee came from prior to the arrest.Â  See State v. Keith, 356 S.C. 219, 225, 588 S.E.2d 145, 148 (Ct. App. 2003) (affirming decision of trial court to admit drug evidence seized pursuant to a search warrant for defendantâ€™s residence where the following facts established probable cause:Â  informantsâ€™ tips regarding drug transactions at the defendantâ€™s home; surveillance by law enforcement; and a traffic stop of the defendant after leaving his residence which revealed the presence of a marijuana â€œbudâ€ and a pipe in the defendantâ€™s vehicle); State v. Scott, 303 S.C. 360, 362-63, 400 S.E.2d 784, 785-86 (Ct. App. 1991)(affirming defendantâ€™s convictions for trafficking in cocaine and unlawfully transporting drugs in a motor vehicle and finding affidavit in support of search warrant was sufficient to establish probable cause where affidavit was based on information from surveillance officers who followed defendant leaving his residence and ultimately arrested him and searched his vehicle which revealed the presence of twenty grams of cocaine).Â  
 
These cases are clearly distinguishable from the instant case.Â  In both Keith and Scott, the defendant was arrested and searched after leaving his residence.Â  Here, Gentile was not arrested.Â  Instead, the surveillance officers followed and arrested a third party.Â  This person, a visitor at Gentileâ€™s residence who had not been searched prior to his arrival, was not a target of their surveillance.Â Â

title: Sheppard v. Justin Enterprises
description: The court determines that the owner of a servient estate cannot unilaterally relocate an express easement for ingress and egress without obtaining the consent of the owner of the dominant estate.
text:
Sheppard v. Justin Enterprises


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				John R. Sheppard and William J. Sheppard, Respondents,
				v.
				Justin Enterprises, a South Carolina General Partnership, Russ Pye and Lee Pye, Appellants.
			
		
	


Appeal From Charleston County
Daniel F. Pieper, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 4245
Heard April 10, 2007 â€“ Filed May 14, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Bonnie Travaglio Hunt and Michael A. Timbes, both of Charleston, for Appellants.Â 
				
				G. Thomas Hill, of Ravenel, for Respondents.
			
		
	

STILWELL, J.:Â  Russ Pye, Lee Pye, and Justin Enterprises (collectively Appellants) relocated an easement appurtenant to property now owned by John R. and William J. Sheppard.Â  On appeal, we affirm the circuit courtâ€™s order requiring Appellants to restore the easement to its original location.Â 
 
FACTS
Appellants and the Sheppards own adjacent tracts of land, which were both derived from a larger tract known as Encampment Plantation.Â  The Sheppardsâ€™ tract (the dominant estate) includes a right of ingress and egress across Appellantsâ€™ tract (the servient estate).Â  This easement originated in a deed conveying to John Carlton Fox the tract the Sheppards now own.Â  The deed conveyed â€œthe right to the use and enjoyment of the Avenue leading from Highway #17 to the property above described . . . for the use of all present and future owners of said property . . . .â€Â 
 
The deed to Fox also references an attached plat that shows the â€œAvenue.â€ Â Prior to the easementâ€™s relocation, access to the dominant estate required one to turn from Highway 17 onto the avenue and continue straight until reaching a cul-de-sac on the servient estate.Â  At that point, one would turn left onto an old dirt road, then almost immediately turn right onto a separate access road, crossing other property before arriving at the dominant estate.Â 
 
In September 2001, Appellants blocked the access to the old dirt road from the cul-de-sac and created a new road between the avenue and the access road.Â  Consequently, when attempting to access the dominant estate, the Sheppards must turn onto the avenue from Highway 17 and make a slight left turn onto the new road.Â  The new road connects with the old dirt road at a point closer to the access road.Â  From the new road, the Sheppards must turn left onto the old dirt road.Â  The right turn from the old dirt road onto the access road remains the same.Â 
 
On May 16, 2002, Developments Unlimited, LLC, the Sheppardsâ€™ immediate predecessor in title, filed suit against Appellants, requesting the circuit court require Appellants to remove their obstructions to the original access point and restore this portion of the easement to its previous condition.Â  The Sheppards were substituted as plaintiffs when they purchased the dominant estate from Developments Unlimited.Â  After a hearing on the merits, the circuit court granted the relief the Sheppards requested.Â 
 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The determination of the extent of a grant of an easement is an action in equity.Â  Tupper v. Dorchester County, 326 S.C. 318, 323, 487 S.E.2d 187, 190 (1997).Â  Accordingly, this court may review the circuit courtâ€™s findings de novo.Â  Hardy v. Aiken, 369 S.C. 160, 164-65, 631 S.E.2d 539, 541 (2006). 
 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.  Restatement (Third) of Property: Servitudes Â§ 4.8 

Appellants contend the circuit court erred in refusing to apply the Restatement (Third) of Property: Â Servitudes Â§ 4.8 (2000 & Supp. 2006) (the Restatement) to allow them to unilaterally relocate the easement.Â  We disagree.
Traditionally, the location of an easement, once selected or fixed, cannot be changed by the owner of the servient estate without the express or implied consent of the owner of the dominant estate. Â Goodwin v. Johnson, 357 S.C. 49, 53, 591 S.E.2d 34, 36 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  The Restatement, however, provides, in pertinent part:

	Except where the location and dimensions are determined by the instrument or circumstances surrounding creation of a servitude, they are determined as follows . . . . (3) [u]nless expressly denied by the terms of an easement . . . the owner of the servient estate is entitled to make reasonable changes in the location or dimensions of an easement, at the servient ownerâ€™s expense, to permit normal use or development of the servient estate, but only if the changes do not (a) significantly lessen the utility of the easement, (b) increase the burdens on the owner of the easement in its use and enjoyment, or (c) frustrate the purpose for which the easement was created.

In Goodwin, this court adopted the Restatement with respect to easements created by necessity.Â  Goodwin at 57-58, 591 S.E.2d at 38.Â  However, the Goodwin court recognized â€œit should be more difficult to relocate an express easement, as it is akin to a contract and is bargained for by the parties.â€Â  Id. at 55, 591 S.E.2d at 37 (emphasis in original).Â  Moreover, we find no indication by our appellate courts that South Carolina would adopt the Restatement with respect to easements acquired by express grant.
Even if the Restatement could afford relief in a case involving an easement created by grant, we hold Appellantsâ€™ case is not one in which the rule should be applied.Â  Specifically, James H. Southard, Jr., the owner of Developments Unlimited, testified that, prior to September 2001, he used the easement to access the dominant estate with his tractor-trailer.Â  After September 2001, he would not attempt to traverse the relocated easement with his heavy equipment.Â  In addition, he complained he was forced to make four turns instead of two, and the turns came closer together, which prevented larger vehicles from making the turns.Â  
 
Nevertheless, Appellants contend that because the Sheppards purchased the dominant estate after the relocation had occurred they cannot claim any right to the original easement.Â  However, we see no reason why the Sheppards should be unable to claim the full extent of the easement rights conveyed to them, which were the same rights given to Fox and Developments Unlimited.Â  Although the purchase agreement between Developments Unlimited and the Sheppards indicates the property is being sold â€œAS IS,â€ the agreement also acknowledges the existence of the ongoing litigation concerning the easement giving the Sheppards an expectation that the easement could be returned to its original location.Â  Moreover, Appellants agree the easement is appurtenant to the dominant estate and not a mere personal privilege.Â  See e.g., Tupper v. Dorchester County, 326 S.C. 318, 325, 487 S.E.2d 187, 191 (1997) (distinguishing between an easement appurtenant and one in gross).Â  Consequently, the proper analysis is to examine whether the relocation increased the burden on the dominant estate, not just the current owners.
We find, as did the trial court, that Appellantsâ€™ actions increased the burden on the dominant estate.Â  Therefore, there was no error in refusing to apply the Restatement rule.
II.  Implied Consent
Appellants also argue Southard impliedly consented to the relocation of the easement.Â  We disagree.
â€œAny action which would tend to deceive or mislead may constitute sufficient grounds for a court to find acquiescence or an implied consent to [a] relocated easement.â€Â  Henning v. Neisz, 268 N.E.2d 310, 316 (Ind. Ct. App. 1971).Â  Here, Appellants presented testimony that Southard asked them to relocate the easement.Â  C. C. Harness, III, an attorney representing Appellants, attempted to negotiate a relocation with the attorney for Southard, but Harness testified no agreement was reached.Â  Russ Pye explained he relocated the easement at the request of Southard, but acknowledged the path of the new road was chosen more by forces of nature (lightning eliminating trees) than by any human choice.Â  Southard specifically testified he did not consent to the relocation of the easement.Â  We find a preponderance of the evidence supports the circuit courtâ€™s decision that Southard did not, impliedly or otherwise, consent to the easementâ€™s relocation.
CONCLUSION
We hold the circuit court properly refused to apply the Restatement to provide relief to Appellants.Â  More particularly, we find the relocation increases the burden on the dominant estate.Â  In addition, a preponderance of the evidence supports the circuit courtâ€™s ruling that Southard did not impliedly consent to the relocation.Â  Therefore, the circuit courtâ€™s decision is
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, J., and CURETON, A.J., concur.
