THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA

<!--
.style1 {font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif}
-->



THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Elenita R. Duckett, Appellant,
        v.
        Ronald R. Goforth and Frank Raymond Greenhough, Defendants, 
        Of Whom Ronald R. Goforth is Respondent.  
      
    
  


Appeal from Greenwood County
Â Billy A. Tunstall, Jr., Family Court Judge

Opinion No. 4246
Submitted May 1, 2007 â€“ Filed May 15, 2007

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
        Matthew P. Turner and J. Michael Turner, Sr., both of Laurens, for Appellant.
        Ronald R. Goforth of Fayetteville, Arkansas, Pro Se Respondent.
      
    
  

ANDERSON, J.:Â  Elenita R. Duckett (â€œDuckettâ€) initiated an action in Greenwood County Family Court to determine paternity and adjudicate custody and child support in regard to Ronald R. Goforth (â€œGoforthâ€).Â  The family court found it lacked jurisdiction to address Duckettâ€™s petition and dismissed the action.Â  We reverse and remand.[1]
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
The minor child â€œH.J.â€ was allegedly conceived as the result of a relationship between Duckett and Goforth while they were in the Philippines.Â  Duckett was married to Frank Raymond Greenhough (Greenhough) who, according to Duckett, was in Australia at the time of H.J.â€™s conception.Â  In June 1994, Duckett learned she was pregnant and informed Goforth.Â  Because she was frightened of having a child on her own, Duckett asked Greenhough for his assistance and they reconciled.Â  Both agreed that Greenhough would serve as H.J.â€™s father.Â  On February 1, 1995, Duckett gave birth in the Philippines.Â  In 1997, Duckett and Greenhough moved from the Philippines to Australia.[2] 
On February 1, 2000, Duckett filed an application for dissolution of the marriage and designated H.J. as a child of the marriage, but on March 30, 2000, Duckett submitted an affidavit in which she averred that Goforth was H.J.â€™s biological father.Â  
On March 27, 2000, the Australian family court issued a Decree Nisi of Dissolution of Marriage between Duckett and Greenhough.Â  The decree incorporated previously issued orders awarding Duckett custody, assigning joint financial responsibility for H.J., and providing Greenhough with visitation rights.Â  The tribunal declared it was satisfied that H.J. was the only child of the marriage and proper arrangements for her welfare had been made.Â  In addition, a restraining order remained in place to prevent either party from removing H.J. from the Western State of Australia without written consent.Â  
On June 4, 2001, Duckett and H.J. left Australia without the Australian courtâ€™s permission and traveled to the United States, where they have remained for the last five years.Â  Duckett settled in Greenwood County and remarried.Â  
On December 14, 2001, Duckett petitioned the Washington County Family Court in the State of Arkansas, where Goforth resided, to determine paternity and award child support. Â Duckett named Goforth as the father but did not name Greenhough as a party or notify him of the proceedings.Â  Goforth moved to dismiss, alleging Arkansas was not H.J.â€™s home state and the Arkansas court lacked jurisdiction.Â  Ultimately, the Arkansas Supreme Court ruled the Washington County Court did not have jurisdiction to hear the petition because Arkansas was not the home state of the child.Â  
On August 27, 2002, Greenhough filed an application in accordance with the Hague Convention for H.J.â€™s return to Australia. Â Two days later, Greenhough filed an application, pursuant to the Hague Convention, for the enforcement of the Australian visitation order.Â  On March 4, 2004, Greenhough filed an application in Australia seeking the return of H.J.Â  The application was dismissed following a hearing on January 24, 2005.
Duckett instituted this action in the Greenwood County Family Court requesting a finding of paternity, child support and other related relief. Â Goforth moved to dismiss, arguing the family court lacked subject matter jurisdiction by virtue of the prior rulings of the Australian and Arkansas courts and the on-going litigation in Australia.Â  Additionally, he alleged the family court lacked personal jurisdiction.Â  He pled res judicata as a defense.Â  The family court issued the following order:Â  

  24. This Court finds that it does lack subject matter jurisdiction.Â  It is clear that the child was born during the marriage of the Plaintiff [Duckett] and husband [Greenhough].Â  There is a presumption that the husband is the father.Â  It is noted that the divorce decree of the Plaintiff and husband made findings in relation to visitation, support and custody of the child between the husband and Plaintiff, and that neither party appealed that ruling. 
  25. Further, that the Plaintiffâ€™s subsequent conduct of applying to the Australian Court for both the divorce and permission to remove the child from Australia reinforces to this Court the continuing effect of that Australian Courtâ€™s order and jurisdiction.Â  
  24.[3]Â Â The Court also finds that since there is a presumption that a child born during the marriage is a product of the husband and wife, Plaintiff must first establish that the husband is not the father of the child before she can bring an action to declare another person (Goforth) as the father.Â  This Court has been provided no proof that this child born of the marriage is not the child of the father.Â  Without such evidence, this Court lacks personal jurisdiction over the Defendant pursuant to SCRCP 12(b)(2).
  25.Â Next, Goforth argues that this matter should be dismissed as this Court must acknowledge and recognize the Australian decrees. . . .Â  Since there has been an adjudication of these matters and recent pending litigation in the Australian Courts, this Court declines to exercise jurisdiction in this instance. 
  26. Finally, Goforth argues that this matter has been litigated and appealed to the highest Court of the State of Arkansas.Â  Additionally, the issue of paternity has been litigated in Australia, and that court has ruled that this is a child of the marriage.Â Â Â  These orders have never been contested or appealed and are final.Â  Specific rulings and findings have been issued, and this Court must give full faith and credit to those orders and findings.Â  This Court agrees. 

Duckett filed a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion for reconsideration, which the family court denied.
ISSUES
I.Â Â Â Did the family court err in concluding it lacked subject matter jurisdiction when South Carolina is the home state of the minor child?
II.Â Â Did the family court err in concluding it did not have personal jurisdiction over Goforth?
III.Â Â Did the family court err in concluding it was without jurisdiction because of a prior Australian decree?
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, this court may find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Nasser-Moghaddassi v. Moghaddassi, 364 S.C. 182, 189, 612 S.E.2d 707, 711 (Ct. App. 2005) (citing Emery v. Smith, 361 S.C. 207, 213, 603 S.E.2d 598, 601 (Ct. App. 2004)).Â  However, this broad scope of review does not require this court to disregard the family courtâ€™s findings.Â  Lacke v. Lacke, 362 S.C. 302, 307, 608 S.E.2d 147, 149 (Ct. App. 2005) (citing Bowers v. Bowers, 349 S.C. 85, 561 S.E.2d 610 (Ct. App. 2002)); Badeaux v. Davis, 337 S.C. 195, 202, 522 S.E.2d 835, 838 (Ct. App 1999).Â  Nor must we ignore the fact that the family court judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony.Â  Scott v. Scott, 354 S.C. 118, 124, 579 S.E.2d 620, 623 (2003) (citing Woodall v. Woodall, 322 S.C. 7, 10, 471 S.E. 2d 154, 157 (1996)).Â  However, our broad scope of review does not relieve the appellant of the burden of convincing this court the family court committed error.Â  Nasser-Moghaddassi, 364 S.C. at 190, 612 S.E.2d at 711 (citing Skinner v. King, 272 S.C. 520, 522-23, 252 S.E.2d 891, 892 (1979)).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Uniform Child Custody Jurisdiction Act (UCCJA)
A. Â Subject Matter Jurisdiction
 Duckett contends South Carolina is the home state of the child and the family court erred in finding it lacked subject matter jurisdiction.Â  We agree.Â  Additionally, Duckett maintains the family court erred in concluding this matter should be dismissed because the court must recognize the Australian decree in accordance with section 20-7-830 of the South Carolina Code (1985).Â  We agree.
â€œThe jurisdiction of a court over the subject matter of a proceeding is determined by the Constitution, the laws of the state, and is fundamental.â€Â  Badeaux v. Davis, 337 S.C. 195, 205, 522 S.E.2d 835, 840 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  Because Duckettâ€™s amended complaint included a request for custody, the jurisdictional question requires analysis under the Uniform Child Custody Jurisdiction Act (UCCJA).[4] Â Â 

  The UCCJA was enacted to:
  (1) avoid jurisdictional competition and conflict with courts in other states in matters of child custody . . . ; (2) promote cooperation with the courts of other states to the end that a custody decree is rendered in that state which can best decide the case in the interest of the child; (3) assure that litigation concerning the custody of a child take place ordinarily in the state with which the child and his family have the closest connection and where significant evidence concerning his care, protection, training and personal relationships is most readily available. . . .

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-784 (1985) (emphasis added).Â  
Under the UCCJA, a state has jurisdiction to make an initial or change in custody determination if 

  (1) this State (i) is the home state of the child at the time of commencement of the proceeding, or (ii) had been the childâ€™s home state within six months before commencement of the proceeding and the child is absent from this State because of his removal or retention by a person claiming his custody or for other reasons, and a parent or person acting as parent continues to live in this State; or
  (2) it is in the best interest of the child that a court of this State assume jurisdiction because (i) the child and his parents, or the child and at least one contestant, have a significant connection with this State and (ii) there is available in this State substantial evidence concerning the childâ€™s present or future care, protection, training and personal relationships; or
  (3) the child is physically present in this State and (i) the child has been abandoned or (ii) it is necessary in an emergency to protect the child because he has been subjected to or threatened with mistreatment or abuse or is otherwise neglected or dependent; or
  (4) (i) it appears that no other state would have jurisdiction under prerequisites substantially in accordance with paragraphs (1), (2) or (3) of subsection (a), or another state has declined to exercise jurisdiction on the ground that this State is the more appropriate forum to determine the custody of the child and (ii) it is in the best interest of the child that this court assume jurisdiction.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-788 (a)(1985); Charest v. Charest, 329 S.C. 511, 518, 495 S.E.2d 784, 787 (Ct. App. 1997); see also Â§ 20-7-788 (b) (suggesting that when another state has declined jurisdiction, physical presence in this state of the child, or of the child and one of the contestants, may be sufficient to confer jurisdiction on a court of this state to make a child custody determination).
South Carolina is unquestionably the home state of this child.Â  â€œHome stateâ€ means the state where the child lived with a parent for at least six consecutive months immediately preceding the time of the action. Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-786(5) (1985); Charest, 329 S.C. at 518, 495 S.E.2d at 788.Â  H.J. has resided with her mother in Greenwood County since June 2001, well over the six consecutive months preceding commencement of this action.Â  Indeed, by the time of this appeal, H.J. will have lived nearly half of her life in South Carolina.Â  Williams v. Williams, 285 S.C. 270, 272, 329 S.E.2d 751, 751 (1985) (holding where mother and child had lived in South Carolina for seven years prior to the action, South Carolina was the home state and the more convenient forum under UCCJA).Â  
Additionally, H.J. has attended the same school in Greenwood County since entering the first grade.Â  All records pertaining to her schooling are in Greenwood County.Â  H.J.â€™s medical care has been provided in Greenwood County since she was six years old.Â  Substantial evidence concerning H.J.â€™s present or future care, protection, training, and personal relationships is available only in South Carolina.Â  Moreover, the Arkansas Supreme Court declined to exercise jurisdiction over the matter, acknowledging that Arkansas was not H.J.â€™s home state.Â  
Goforth considers Australia the â€œdecree state.â€ Â A South Carolina court may not modify a decree from another state unless: â€œ(1) it appears to the court of this State that the court which rendered the decree does not now have jurisdiction under jurisdictional prerequisites substantially in accordance with this subarticle or has declined to assume jurisdiction to modify the decree and (2) the court of this State has jurisdiction.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-810(a) (1985).Â  The UCCJA defines â€œstateâ€ as â€œany state, territory or possession of the United States, the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico and the District of Columbia.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-786(10) (1985).Â  
Concomitantly, Goforth suggests that section 20-7-830 requires South Carolina courts to recognize the continuing jurisdiction of the Australian tribunal.Â  Â This section applies UCCJA provisions relating to the recognition and enforcement of decrees issued by other states â€œto custody decrees and decrees involving legal institutions similar in nature to custody, rendered by appropriate authorities of other nations if reasonable notice and opportunity to be heard were given to all affected persons.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann Â§ 20-7-830 (1985). [5]
The parties dispute whether a foreign country is the same as another state under the UCCJA.Â  We need not reach that determination.Â  Even if Australia were recognized as the â€œdecree state,â€ it no longer retains jurisdiction under jurisdictional prerequisites substantially in accordance with the UCCJA.Â  Â§ 20-7-810(a)(1), supra. Â 
Although more than one state may meet the jurisdictional requirements under the UCCJA, once a custody decree has been entered, the continuing jurisdiction of the decree state is exclusive.Â  Charest v. Charest, 329 S.C. 511, 518, 495 S.E.2d 784, 788 (Ct. App. 1997) (citingÂ  Sinclair v. Albrecht, 287 S.C. 20, 336 S.E.2d 485 (Ct. App. 1985)). Â Jurisdiction continues if one parent resides in the decree state and substantial evidence remains there, even though another state has become the childâ€™s home state. Â Id.Â  A court may exercise continuing jurisdiction when â€œthere are sufficient contacts with the child and his parent(s) to justify legitimate state interest in the outcome of the dispute, and if sufficient evidence is available to enable the court to make a fair determination of custody based upon the best interest of the child.â€ Â Widdicombe v. Tucker-Cales, 366 S.C. 75, 87, 620 S.E.2d 333, 340 (Ct. App. 2005) (quoting Cullen v. Prescott, 302 S.C. 201, 206, 394 S.E.2d 722, 725 (Ct. App. 1990)).
On the other hand, if connection with the decree state ends because all parties involved have moved away or contact with the decree state has become slight, another state may assume jurisdiction to modify the decree. Â Knoth v. Knoth, 297 S.C. 460, 463, 377 S.E.2d 340, 342 (1989) (explaining that jurisdiction of the decree state is exclusive and continues unless the state no longer meets the jurisdictional requirements or declines to exercise jurisdiction) (emphasis added).Â  The South Carolina family court may obtain jurisdiction if it is in the best interest of the child because (1) the child and his parents, or the child and at least one contestant, have a significant connection with the state and (2) substantial evidence is available in the state concerning the childâ€™s present or future care, protection, training, and personal relationships.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-788 (a)(2) (1985) (emphasis added).Â  
â€œCourts will exercise jurisdiction based upon these criteria if there are sufficient contacts with the child and his parent(s) to justify legitimate state interest in the outcome of the dispute, and if sufficient evidence is available to enable the court to make a fair determination of custody based upon the best interest of the child.â€Â  Cullen v. Prescott, 302 S.C. 201, 206, 394 S.E.2d 722, 725 (Ct. App. 1990).
In Cullen, 302 S.C. at 205, 394 S.E.2d at 724, we reversed the family courtâ€™s conclusion that it did not have jurisdiction to modify a Georgia custody decree.Â  We found section 20-7-788(a)(2) provides South Carolina courts may assume jurisdiction of a custody dispute upon a finding that it is in the best interest of the child to do so, if the child and a parent have significant connection with this state and substantial evidence is available in the state concerning the childâ€™s present or future care, protection, training and personal relationships. Â Cullen, 302 S.C. at 205, 394 S.E.2d at 724.
Our reasoning in Cullen applies to the circumstances in the case sub judice.Â  H.J. has not lived in Australia since 2001 but has lived in South Carolina with her mother nearly half of her life.Â  Evidence concerning her present and future welfare is available only in South Carolina.Â  Moreover, contact with Australia has become so slight that it no longer meets jurisdictional requirements under section 20-7-788(a).Â  Because the Australian tribunal no longer has jurisdiction over the matter, South Carolina has jurisdiction and can modify the prior custody decree as the home state.Â  It is in H.J.â€™s best interest that the question of paternity be resolved.Â  To ensure that custody litigation takes place where H.J. has the closest connection, the South Carolina family court should adjudicate the issues in this case.Â  
Furthermore, South Carolina has a legitimate interest in the outcome of this dispute where it affects welfare and protection of its young citizenry.Â  The legislature has granted the family court broad and comprehensive authority in providing for children in this State.Â  21 S.C. Jur. Children and Families, Â§ 153.Â  To that end, the family court has exclusive jurisdiction to hear and determine proceedings to compel the support of a child; to include in the requirements of an order for support the providing of necessary shelter, food, clothing, care, medical attention, expenses of confinement, both before and after the birth, the expense of educating his or her child and other proper and reasonable expenses; to require persons able to provide support to pay a fair and reasonable sum on a periodic basis; to make orders for support until the child is eighteen years of age or is emancipated or where there are physical or mental disabilities; to determine the manner in which child support is paid, that is, directly or through the court; to require a person ordered to support another to give security; to hold those persons who violate court orders with regard to child support in contempt and to sentence them appropriately; to modify or vacate any order; and to make any order necessary to carry out and enforce the provisions of the Code, all without the intervention of a jury.Â  Id. (citing S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-420 (Supp. 2006)).Â Â Â  
â€œThe only limitation upon the courtâ€™s power to provide for the maintenance of children, including security therefor, is that such provision shall be just and equitable, considered in the light of the circumstances of the parties, the nature of the case, and the best interests of the children.â€Â  Id. (citing Fender v. Fender, 256 S. C. 399, 408, 182 S. E. 2d 755, 759 (1971)).
B. Venue
Duckett asserts that South Carolina is the proper venue to determine the issues in this case.Â  We agree.Â  
â€œEven if South Carolina has jurisdiction to consider a custody issue, the Family Court in its discretion may decline to exercise jurisdiction if it finds that it is an inconvenient forum to make a custody determination under the circumstances and another State is a more appropriate forum.â€Â  Charest v Charest, 329 S.C. 511, 519, 495 S.E.2d 784, 788 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  

  In determining whether it is an inconvenient forum, the UCCJA provides a court should consider whether it is in the childâ€™s interest that another state assume jurisdiction by evaluating the following factors, among others: (1) If another state is or recently was the childâ€™s home state; (2) If another state has a closer connection with the child and his family or with the child and one or more of the contestants; (3) If substantial evidence concerning the childâ€™s present or future care, protection, training and personal relationships are more readily available in another state; (4) if the parties have agreed on another forum which is no less appropriate;(5) If the exercise of jurisdiction by a court of this State would contravene any of the purposes state in Â§ 20-7-784.

Id. (citing S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-796(c) (1985)).
As H.J.â€™s home state for nearly one-half of her life, South Carolina has the most significant connections with her present and future welfare.Â  No other State or country has a closer connection to H.J. and her mother.Â  Substantial evidence of H.J.â€™s care, protection, training and personal relationships are NOT more readily available in another state.Â  Accordingly, under these circumstances we rule South Carolina is not an inconvenient forum in which to adjudicate the issues in this action.
C.Â Personal Jurisdiction
Duckett argues the trial court erred in determining the family court did not have personal jurisdiction over Goforth.Â  We agree. 
The UCCJA establishes that personal jurisdiction of an out of state resident may be obtained if the following requirements are satisfied:

  Â (a) Notice required for the exercise of jurisdiction over a person outside this State shall be given in a manner reasonably calculated to give actual notice, and may be:
  
    (1) by personal delivery outside this State in the manner prescribed for service of process within this State;
    (2) in the manner prescribed by the law of the place in which the service is made for service of process in that place in an action in any of its courts of general jurisdiction;
    (3) by any form of mail addressed to the person to be served and requesting a receipt;
    (4) as directed by the court, including publication, if other means of notification are ineffective.
  
  (b) Notice under this section shall be served, mailed or delivered, or last published, at least twenty days before any hearing in this State. Â Provided, however, that in proceedings pursuant to Â§ 20-7-788 (a) (3) above, upon a showing by the moving party that an emergency or abandonment situation exists within the meaning of Â§ 20-7-788 (a) (3) so as to place the child in jeopardy, the court may shorten the notice period to such period as it may deem to be in the best interests of the child.
  (c) Proof of service outside this State may be made by affidavit of the individual who made the service, or in the manner prescribed by the law of this State, the order pursuant to which the service is made, or the law of the place in which the service is made. Â If service is made by mail, proof may be a receipt signed by the addressee or other evidence of delivery to the addressee.
  (d) Notice is not required if a person submits to the jurisdiction of the court.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-792 (1985). 
Service on Goforth was properly effected at least twenty days prior to the April 11, 2005 hearing on his motion. Â Importantly, Goforth appeared for the purpose of contesting jurisdiction in his motion to dismiss, indicating he had actual notice of the proceedings.Â  Duckett satisfied the service of process requirements under the applicable law of this State to give the family court personal jurisdiction over Goforth.Â Â  Accordingly, we hold the family court erred in finding it lacked personal jurisdiction.
The family court, nonetheless, determined it lacked personal jurisdiction over Goforth because no evidence existed to rebut the presumption that Greenhough was H.J.â€™s father.Â  
â€œThe presumption of legitimacy, although rebuttable, is one of the strongest known to law.â€Â  Hudson v. Blanton, 282 S.C. 70, 75, 316 S.E.2d 432, 434 (Ct. App. 1984) (citing Barrâ€™s Next of Kin v. Cherokee, Inc., 220 S.C. 447, 68 S.E.2d 440 (1951).Â  â€œEvery child born in wedlock is presumed to be legitimate.â€Â  Id. (citing Tarleton v. Thompson, 125 S.C. 182, 118 S.E. 421 (1923)).Â  The presumption of a husbandâ€™s access to his wife â€œmust be overcome by the clearest evidence that it was impossible for him, by reason of impotency or imbecility, or entire absence from the place where the wife was during the period of conception,â€ to have fathered the child. Â Id. at 75, 316 S.E.2d at 435 (citations omitted).Â  
It strains the imagination to conceive of a more persuasive record rebutting the presumption of paternity.Â  Admittedly, Greenhough signed H.J.â€™s birth certificate at Duckettâ€™s request and agreed to be H.J.â€™s father because Duckett feared raising a child on her own.Â  However, Greenhoughâ€™s January 12, 2000 affidavit indicated he and Duckett understood Greenhough was not H.J.â€™s biological father.Â  Greenhough claimed he was infertile and he never acknowledged paternity.Â  Shortly after filing her 2001 petition for divorce in Australia, Duckett named Goforth the putative biological father.Â  Her affidavit of April 11, 2005 alleged Greenhough was unable to father a child and was not H.J.â€™s biological father.Â  Additionally, Duckett explained she believed Goforth was the biological father because they were sexually involved when H.J. was conceived, and she was not having a sexual relationship with her husband at the time of conception.Â  Significantly, Greenhough was physically located in Australia when H.J. was conceived in the Phillipines.Â  
The testimony of a husband and wife as to â€œany relevant matterâ€ is admissible on the issue of paternity, including testimony regarding parentage and marriage.Â  Roy T. Stuckey, Marital Litigation in South Carolina 359 (3d ed. 2001) (citing S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-956 (A)(8) (1976).Â  Although irrelevant to the determination that the family court had personal jurisdiction over Goforth, we conclude Duckettâ€™s evidence sufficiently rebutted the presumption of Greenhoughâ€™s paternity.Â  
II. Â Res judicata
Duckett claims the family court erred in finding custody, child support, and paternity had been litigated in Australia and in affording full faith and credit to the Australian tribunalâ€™s ruling.Â  We agree. 
Though not specifically referring to the doctrine of res judicata in its order, it appears the family court intended to rule that either res judicata or collateral estoppel barred litigation of the issues in the present action. 
Res judicata precludes parties from subsequently relitigating issues actually litigated and those that might have been litigated in a prior action.Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Basnight, 346 S.C. 241, 249, 551 S.E.2d 274, 278 (Ct. App. 2001) (citation omitted).Â  The doctrine flows from the principle that public interest requires an end to litigation and no one should be sued twice for the same cause of action.Â  Town of Sullivanâ€™s Island v. Felger, 318 S.C. 340, 344, 457 S.E.2d 626, 628 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  â€œRes judicata is the branch of the law that defines the effect a valid judgment may have on subsequent litigation between the same parties and their privies. Â Res judicata ends litigation, promotes judicial economy and avoids the harassment of relitigation of the same issues.â€ Â Nelson v. QHG of S.C., Inc., 354 S.C. 290, 304, 580 S.E.2d 171, 178 (Ct. App. 2003) (quoting James F. Flanagan, South Carolina Civil Procedure 642 (2d ed. 1996)) revâ€™d in part on other grounds, 362 S.C. 421, 608 S.E.2d 855 (2005).Â  A party seeking to preclude litigation on the grounds of res judicata must show: (1) identity of the parties; (2) identity of the subject matter; and (3) adjudication of the issue on the merits in the former suit by a court of competent jurisdiction. Â Plum Creek Dev. Co. v. City of Conway, 334 S.C. 30, 34, 512 S.E.2d 106, 109 (1999). Â 
Res judicata does not bar the present litigation.Â  The parties to the Australian litigation were Duckett and Greenhough; Goforth and Duckett are parties in the present litigation.Â  The subject of the Australian proceeding was adjudication of custody, child support, visitation, and other related issues between Duckett and Greenhough.Â  The action here is for determination of paternity, an award of custody, and child support between Duckett and Goforth.Â  The issues of custody and child support have never been litigated between Duckett and Goforth.Â  Moreover, the issue of paternity was not fully and finally adjudicated by the Australian tribunal.[6]Â  
â€œCollateral estoppel prevents a party from relitigating in a subsequent suit an issue actually and necessarily litigated and determined in a prior action.â€ Â Â Stone v. Roadway Express, 367 S.C. 575, 580, 627 S.E.2d 695, 698 (2006).Â  

  A party may assert nonmutual collateral estoppel to prevent relitigation of a previously litigated issue unless the party sought to be precluded did not have a fair and full opportunity to litigate the issue in the first proceeding, or unless other circumstances justify providing the party an opportunity to relitigate the issue. 

Wade v. Berkeley County, 330 S.C. 311, 317, 498 S.E.2d 684, 688 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  However, collateral estoppel is an affirmative defense which must be pled and because Goforth never raised the defense, he may not invoke the defense on appeal.Â  Jordan v. Jordan, 284 S.C. 342, 346, 326 S.E.2d 416, 418 (Ct. App. 1985) (holding defensive collateral estoppel is an affirmative defense and thus, must be plead).
Notwithstanding this procedural roadblock, collateral estoppel would not preclude Duckett from asserting a paternity claim against Goforth.Â  Paternity was not â€œactually and necessarily litigated and determinedâ€ in the prior Australian proceeding.Â  The family court erred in concluding the Australian decree constituted a determination of paternity.Â  
Paternity is defined as â€œthe state or condition of a father; the relationship of a father.â€Â  Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary 1126 (6th ed. 1990).Â  Determining parentage is inextricably linked to this Stateâ€™s strong interest in the protection of its children and provision for their welfare.Â  Sections 20-7-952 through 958 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2006) encapsulate the legislatureâ€™s policies in this regard: 
An action to establish the paternity of an individual may be brought by:

  (1) A child;
  (2) The natural mother of a child;
  (3) Any person in whose care a child has been placed;
  (4) An authorized agency, including, but not limited to, the Department of Social Services, pursuant to the provisions of Chapter 5 of Title 43, and any other person or agency pursuant to the provisions of Â§Â§ 20-7-435 and 20- 7-840; or
  (5) A person who claims to be the father of a child.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-952 (C) (Supp. 2006).Â  

  As soon as practicable after an action has been commenced, the court, upon its motion or that of an interested party, may order the natural mother, the putative father, and the child to submit to genetic tests such as red blood cell antigen testing, human leukocyte antigen (HLA) testing, electrophoresis, or other tests which have been developed for the purpose of proving or disproving parentage and which are reasonably accessible. . . .
  For all child support cases not administered under Title IV-D of the Social Security Act, the child and all parties in a contested paternity case, upon the request of any party to the action, must be ordered by the court to submit to the genetic testing, as provided for in subsection (A), to determine paternity.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-954 (A), (C) (Supp. 2006). 

  Upon a finding that the putative father is the natural father of the child, the court must issue an order designating the putative father as the natural father. Â The order also shall set forth the social security numbers, or the alien identification numbers assigned to resident aliens who do not have social security numbers, of both parents. Â The order shall establish a duty of support and provide for child support payments in amounts and at a frequency to be determined by the court. Â The order also shall provide for other relief which has been properly prayed for in the pleadings and which is considered reasonable and just by the court. Â Upon a finding that the putative father is not the father of the child, the court shall issue an order which sets forth this finding.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-957 (Supp. 2006).
The Australian tribunal found that H.J. was a â€œchild of the marriageâ€ in the context of issuing the divorce decree.Â  As Duckett points out in her brief on appeal â€œ â€˜child of the marriageâ€™ for the purposes of use in a[n Australian] Decree Nisi for dissolution of marriage is defined as child (including an ex-nuptial child of either the husband or the wife, a child adopted by either of them or a child who is not a child of either of them) is a child of the marriage, if the child was treated by the husband and wife as a child of their family at the relevant time.â€™ â€ Appellantâ€™s Brief on Appeal (citing Australian Family Law Act Â§ 55A(3) Part VIÂ  (1975)).Â  Notably, a â€œchild of the marriageâ€ in Australia may include children who are not the biological progeny of either spouse.
In South Carolina, a paternity determination for the purposes of child support relates to the natural or biological relationship between father and child.Â  See S.C. Code Ann Â§Â§ 20-7-952 through 958 (Supp. 2006).Â  While a child born during a marriage is the presumed legitimate child of the husband, that presumption may be rebutted by a paternity determination.Â  Douglass ex rel. Louthian v. Boyce, 344 S.C. 5, 8, 542 S.E.2d 715, 716-17 (2001) (interpreting S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-952 (E) (1985)).Â  Treating a child as a child of the family during the marriage does not rise to the level of a paternity determination in South Carolina.Â  Accordingly, it is incumbent on the family court to address the question of Goforthâ€™s paternity in order to assure H.J. is supported in a manner consistent with South Carolinaâ€™s legislative mandate. Â 
CONCLUSION
We hold that South Carolina is unquestionably the home state of the minor child and the proper venue for adjudication of the issues presented herein.Â  The Australian tribunal no longer satisfies jurisdictional requirements under the UCCJA to retain jurisdiction over matters involving H.J.â€™s interests.Â  We rule personal jurisdiction over Goforth was properly obtained according to the applicable provisions of the UCCJA. Â Neither res judicata nor collateral estoppel bars this action.Â  The prior Australian proceeding involved different parties and the issue of paternity was never fully and finally litigated.Â  
Accordingly, the order of the family court dismissing this action is 
REVERSED and REMANDED.
HUFF and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] At some point, Duckett became an Australian citizen.
[3] Numbering error is exactly as it appears in the record.
[4] The UCCJA was adopted in South Carolina in 1981 and codified in the South Carolina Code of Laws sections 20-7-782 through 830 (1985).Â  See Sinclair v. Albrecht, 287 S.C. 20, 21, 336 S.E.2d 485, 486 (Ct. App. 1985).
[5] In order to invoke section 20-7-830, all parties affected by the Australian proceeding must have been afforded reasonable notice and opportunity to be heard on the issue of paternity, assuming, as Goforth claims, that paternity was actually litigated.Â  As the putative biological father Goforth was an affected party.Â  Yet, nothing in the record indicates he received any notification of the proceeding.Â  Therefore, Goforthâ€™s reliance on section 20-7-830 to have the Australian decree recognized and enforced by the South Carolina family court is misplaced. 
[6] The Arkansas Supreme Court determined it lacked subject matter jurisdiction and dismissed Duckettâ€™s action, thus never reaching the merits.Â  Accordingly, res judicata based on the Arkansas litigation does not bar the present action.Â

title: State v. Moore
description: Larry Gene Moore challenges his conviction of armed robbery.  He alleges the charge of armed robbery was improper because the evidence does not show he used force or intimidation to take Wal-Martâ€™s merchandise, but only to retain the property and escape.  We disagree.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Larry Gene Moore, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Roger L. Couch, Special Circuit Court Judge 

Opinion No. 4247
Submitted May 1, 2007 â€“ Filed May 18, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General Deborah R.J. Shupe, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Harold W. Gowdy, III, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
			
		
	

ANDERSON, J.:Â  Larry Gene Moore appeals his conviction of armed robbery.Â  He argues the evidence does not show he used force or intimidation in his asportation of stolen property.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On January 17, 2004, Mark Hayes, a loss prevention officer at a Wal-Mart store in Spartanburg, was on duty when he observed a shopper, Larry Gene Moore, exhibiting suspicious behavior.Â  Only minutes earlier, Hayes noticed the customer had placed several items of merchandise in his shopping cart, and thus became alarmed when he realized Mooreâ€™s cart was presently vacuous.Â  Hayes witnessed Moore pick up a package of over-the-counter medication from the shelf, place it inside his jacket, and begin walking toward the door.
Hayes approached Moore shortly after he stepped outside onto the storeâ€™s sidewalk.Â  After identifying himself and his position with Wal-Mart, Hayes informed Moore he needed to speak with him regarding some unpaid merchandise.Â  During the time Hayes was talking, Moore began digging around in his back pocket.Â  At first, Hayes believed Moore might be looking for a receipt.Â  However, when Moore stated, â€œWhat this, are you sure,â€ Hayes looked down at Mooreâ€™s hand to discover the thief was brandishing a semiautomatic .22 caliber handgun.Â  
 
Fearing for his own safety and that of Wal-Martâ€™s customers, Hayes immediately ended the encounter and went back into the building to make certain the police were apprised of the situation.Â  Moore walked off of Wal-Martâ€™s premises but was apprehended by police a short time later.Â  $454.60 in unpaid Wal-Mart merchandise was recovered from Mooreâ€™s possession.Â  
 
Moore was charged with armed robbery.Â  At the close of the Stateâ€™s case, he moved for a directed verdict and requested the charge be lowered to petty larceny.Â  Moore argued, inter alia, that armed robbery could not be proven because asportation of the property occurred before the confrontation and no force or threat of force was used to take the merchandise.Â  After extensive arguments, the trial judge denied the motion for a directed verdict, finding the offense of armed robbery requires asportation, which includes the escape.Â  It was during the commission of the crime that Moore threatened use of the weapon.Â  At the close of the evidence, Moore renewed his directed verdict motion.Â  The motion was denied. Â Moore was convicted of armed robbery and sentenced to fifteen years.Â 
 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In criminal cases, an appellate court sits to review errors of law only.Â  State v. Baccus, 367 S.C. 41, 48, 625 S.E.2d 216, 220 (2006); State v. Douglas, 367 S.C. 498, 506, 626 S.E.2d 59, 63 (Ct. App. 2006) cert. pending; State v. Wood, 362 S.C. 520, 525, 608 S.E.2d 435, 438 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Thus, an appellate court is bound by the trial courtâ€™s factual findings unless they are clearly erroneous.Â  State v. Quattlebaum, 338 S.C. 441, 527 S.E.2d 105 (2000); State v. Patterson, 367 S.C. 219, 625 S.E.2d 239 (Ct. App. 2006); State v. Landis, 362 S.C. 97, 101, 606 S.E.2d 503, 504 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  This Court does not re-evaluate the facts based on its own view of the preponderance of the evidence but simply determines whether the trial judgeâ€™s ruling is supported by any evidence. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 545 S.E.2d 827 (2001); State v. Mattison, 352 S.C. 577, 575 S.E.2d 852 (Ct. App. 2003).
â€œThe appellate court may reverse the trial judgeâ€™s denial of a motion for a directed verdict only if there is no evidence to support the judgeâ€™s ruling.â€Â  State v. Zeigler, 364 S.C. 94, 103, 610 S.E.2d 859, 863 (Ct. App. 2005) (citing State v. Gaster, 349 S.C. 545, 564 S.E.2d 87 (2002)).Â  On appeal, we are limited to determining whether the trial judge abused his discretion.Â  State v. Reed, 332 S.C. 35, 503 S.E.2d 747 (1998); Douglas, 367 S.C. at 506, 626 S.E.2d at 63; State v. Walker, 366 S.C. 643, 623 S.E.2d 122 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when a ruling is based on an error of law or a factual conclusion that is without evidentiary support.Â  Fields v. Regional Med. Ctr. Orangeburg, 363 S.C. 19, 609 S.E.2d 506 (2005); Renney v. Dobbs House, Inc., 275 S.C. 562, 274 S.E.2d 290 (1981); see also Simon v. Flowers, 231 S.C. 545, 550, 99 S.E.2d 391, 393-94 (1957) (â€œ â€˜[E]rror at lawâ€™ exists: (1) when the circuit judge, in issuing [the order], was controlled by some error of law ... or (2) where the order, based upon factual, as distinguished from legal, considerations, is without adequate evidentiary support.â€); McSween v. Windham, 77 S.C. 223, 226, 57 S.E. 847, 848 (1907) (â€œ[T]he determination of the court will not be interfered with, unless there is an abuse of discretion, or unless the exercise of discretion was controlled by some error of law.â€).
When ruling on a motion for a directed verdict, the trial judge is concerned with the existence or nonexistence of evidence, not its weight.Â  State v. Weston, 367 S.C. 279, 625 S.E.2d 641 (2006); Sellers v. State, 362 S.C. 182, 607 S.E.2d 82 (2005); State v. Cherry, 361 S.C. 588, 606 S.E.2d 475 (2004);Â  State v. Rosemond, 356 S.C. 426, 430, 589 S.E.2d 757, 758-59 (2003); State v. McHoney, 344 S.C. 85, 544 S.E.2d 30 (2001).Â  A case should be submitted to the jury if there is any direct evidence or any substantial circumstantial evidence that reasonably tends to prove the guilt of the accused or from which guilt may be fairly and logically deduced.Â  State v. Walker, 349 S.C. 49, 562 S.E.2d 313 (2002); State v. Buckmon, 347 S.C. 316, 555 S.E.2d 402 (2001); State v. Al-Amin, 353 S.C. 405, 411, 578 S.E.2d 32, 35 (Ct. App. 2003); see also State v. Martin, 340 S.C. 597, 533 S.E.2d 572 (2000) (stating where the evidence is circumstantial, a trial court has the duty to submit a case to jury so long as there is substantial circumstantial evidence that reasonably tends to prove guilt of accused or from which his guilt may be fairly and logically deduced). Â â€œ[I]n ruling on a motion for directed verdict, the trial court must view the evidence in the light most favorable to the State.â€Â  State v. Prince, 316 S.C. 57, 64, 447 S.E.2d 177, 181-82 (1993).Â  Â 
A defendant is entitled to a directed verdict when the State fails to produce evidence of the offense charged.Â  State v. McKnight, 352 S.C. 635, 642, 576 S.E.2d 168, 171 (2003); State v. Rothschild, 351 S.C. 238, 243, 569 S.E.2d 346, 348 (2002); State v. Padgett, 354 S.C. 268, 580 S.E.2d 159 (Ct. App. 2003); State v. Wilds, 355 S.C. 269, 274, 584 S.E.2d 138, 141 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  The trial court should grant a directed verdict motion when the evidence merely raises a suspicion that the accused is guilty.Â  State v. Arnold, 361 S.C. 386, 605 S.E.2d 529 (2004); State v. Schrock, 283 S.C. 129, 132, 322 S.E.2d 450, 452 (1984); State v. Horne, 324 S.C. 372, 379, 478 S.E.2d 289, 293 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  â€œSuspicionâ€ implies a belief or opinion as to guilt that is based upon facts or circumstances that do not amount to proof.Â  Cherry, 361 S.C. at 594, 606 S.E.2d at 478; State v. Lollis, 343 S.C. 580, 541 S.E.2d 254 (2001); Zeigler 364 S.C. at 103, 610 S.E.2d at 863.Â  A trial judge is not required to find that the evidence infers guilt to the exclusion of any other reasonable hypotheses.Â  Cherry, 361 S.C. at 594, 606 S.E.2d at 478; State v. Ballenger, 322 S.C. 196, 470 S.E.2d 851 (1996).
On appeal from the denial of a directed verdict in a criminal case, an appellate court must view the evidence and all reasonable inferences in the light most favorable to the State.Â  State v. Curtis, 356 S.C. 622, 591 S.E.2d 600 (2004); State v. Wilds, 355 S.C. at 274, 584 S.E.2d at 141; State v. Morgan, 352 S.C. 359, 364, 574 S.E.2d 203, 205 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  If there is any direct evidence or any substantial circumstantial evidence reasonably tending to prove the guilt of the accused, this Court must find the case was properly submitted to the jury. Â State v. Harris, 351 S.C. 643, 653, 572 S.E.2d 267, 273 (2002); State v. Condrey, 349 S.C. 184, 190, 562 S.E.2d 320, 323 (Ct. App. 2002); State v. Patterson, 337 S.C. 215, 232, 522 S.E.2d 845, 853 (Ct. App. 1999). 
 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Moore argues the trial court erred in refusing to direct a verdict of acquittal on the charge of armed robbery.Â  He alleges the charge of armed robbery was improper because the evidence does not show he used force or intimidation to take Wal-Martâ€™s merchandise, but only to retain the property and escape.Â  We disagree.
1. THE LAW EXTANT AS TO ARMED ROBBERY 
Armed robbery occurs when a person commits robbery while either armed with a deadly weapon or alleging to be armed by the representation of a deadly weapon. Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-11-330 (2003); see also State v. Al-Amin, 353 S.C. 405, 424, 578 S.E.2d 32, 42 (Ct. App. 2003) (â€œArmed robbery occurs when a person commits robbery either while armed with a deadly weapon or while the person was alleging he was armed and was using a representation of a deadly weapon.â€). Â Included in armed robbery is the lesser included offense of robbery.Â  State v. Scipio, 283 S.C. 124, 125-126, 322 S.E.2d 15, 16 (1984). Â Our statutory scheme specifies that the definition of robbery is to be provided by South Carolinaâ€™s common law. Â See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-11-325 (2003) (stating: â€œThe common law offense of robbery is a felony. Â Upon conviction, a person must be imprisoned not more than fifteen years.â€); see also Al-Amin, 353 S.C. at 424, 578 S.E.2d at 42 (â€œOur statutory scheme provides that the crime of robbery is defined by the common law.â€).
â€œRobbery is defined as the felonious or unlawful taking of money, goods, or other personal property of any value from the person of another or in his presence by violence or by putting such person in fear.â€Â  Al-Amin, 353 S.C. at 424, 578 S.E.2d at 42 (citing State v. Parker, 351 S.C. 567, 571 S.E.2d 288 (2002); Joseph v. State, 351 S.C. 551, 571 S.E.2d 280 (2002)). Â Our supreme court has described robbery as â€œthe felonious taking and carrying away of goods of another against the will or without consent.â€Â  State v. Scipio, 283 S.C. 124, 126, 322 S.E.2d 15, 16 (1984).Â  â€œThe gravamen of a robbery charge is a taking from the person or immediate presence of another by violence or intimidation.â€ Â State v. Rosemond, 356 S.C. 426, 430, 589 S.E.2d 757, 758-59 (2003) (citing State v. Hiott, 276 S.C. 72, 276 S.E.2d 163 (1981)).Â  â€œWhen determining whether the robbery was committed with intimidation, the trial court should determine whether an ordinary, reasonable person in the victimâ€™s position would feel a threat of bodily harm from the perpetratorâ€™s acts.â€Â  Rosemond, 356 S.C. at 430, 589 S.E.2d at 759.
The elements of robbery and armed robbery include asportation of the property.Â  State v. Keith, 283 S.C. 597, 598, 325 S.E.2d 325, 326 (1985.
â€œThe common-law offense of robbery is essentially the commission of larceny with force.â€ State v. Brown, 274 S.C. 48, 49, 260 S.E.2d 719, 720 (1979). Â â€œIn common parlance[,] larceny is just plain stealing.â€ Â State v. Roof, 196 S.C. 204, 209, 12 S.E.2d 705, 707 (1941); see also Gill v. Ruggles, 95 S.C. 90, 78 S.E. 536 (1913) (noting that â€œstealingâ€ is the popular word for the technical word â€œlarcenyâ€).Â  Larceny is the felonious taking and carrying away of the goods of another against the ownerâ€™s will or without his consent.â€ Â Al-Amin, 353 S.C. at 424, 578 S.E.2d at 42 (citing Broom v. State, 351 S.C. 219, 569 S.E.2d 336 (2002); State v. Condrey, 349 S.C. 184, 562 S.E.2d 320 (Ct.App.2002)). Â Larceny is a lesser-included offense of the crime of armed robbery. Â See State v. Parker, 351 S.C. at 570-71, 571 S.E.2d at 290 (â€œLarceny has been found to be a lesser-included offense of robbery by this Court on several occasions.â€); State v. Austin, 299 S.C. 456, 385 S.E.2d 830 (1989) (petit larceny is a lesser-included of strong armed robbery); State v. Harkness, 288 S.C. 136, 341 S.E.2d 631 (1986) (petit larceny is a lesser included offense of robbery). Â â€œLarceny is also implicit within the crime of shoplifting.â€Â  Al-Amin, 353 S.C. 405, 424, 578 S.E.2d 32, 42; see also S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-13-110 (2003) (defining the offense of shoplifting).Â  
 
Thus, it is the use or alleged use of a deadly weapon that distinguishes armed robbery from robbery, and the employment of force or threat of force that differentiates a robbery from a larceny.Â  See Scipio 283 S.C. at 126, 322 S.E.2d at 16 (the additional element of being armed with a deadly weapon distinguishes robbery and armed robbery); Brown, 274 S.C. at 49, 260 S.E.2d at 720 (adding force to larceny creates the common-law offense of robbery). Â 
2. THE CONTINUOUS OFFENSE THEORYÂ  
State v. Keith, 283 S.C. 597, 325 S.E.2d 325 (1985), is edifying.Â  In Keith, although unarmed at the time the confrontation began, the defendant accosted a man walking along a public street.Â  After rifling through the victimâ€™s pockets and taking the cash from his wallet, the defendant found the victimâ€™s pocketknife and stabbed the man repeatedly.Â  The assailant was convicted of armed robbery and on appeal contended the conviction was improper because he did not become armed until after having taken the victimâ€™s money.Â  The South Carolina Supreme Court disagreed:

	[W]e hold that when a defendant commits robbery without a deadly weapon, but becomes armed with a deadly weapon before asportation of the victimâ€™s property, a conviction for armed robbery will stand. â€œ[T]he robber need not be armed at all times during the robbery in order to be guilty of (armed robbery). [H]e is guilty . . . if he arms himself or becomes armed with a deadly weapon at any time during the progress of the taking or while the robbery is being perpetrated . . .
	[T]he crime of robbery is not completed the moment the stolen property is in the possession of the robbers, but may be deemed to continue during their attempt to escape.â€ Â 77 C.J.S.
	Robbery, Â§ 25 (1952). See also, State v. Bridges, 444 So.2d 721 (La. App. 1984); 
	People v. Heller, 131 Ill.App.2d 799, 267 N.E.2d 685 (Ill. 1971).

Id., 283 S.C. at 598-99, 325 S.E.2d at 326 (emphasis added) (ellipses and parenthesis in the original).
Keith pellucidly adopts the â€œcontinuous offense theory.â€Â  In the context of robbery, the continuous offense theory provides that the crime has occurred â€œnot only if the perpetrator uses force or intimidation to â€˜takeâ€™ possession of the property, but also if force or intimidation is used to retain possession immediately after the taking, or to carry away the property, or to facilitate escape.â€ Â State v. Meyers, 620 So.2d 1160, 1163 (La. 1993) (citing Charles E. Torcia, 4 Whartonâ€™s Criminal Law Â§ 478 (14th ed.1981)); see also People v. Randolph, 648 N.W.2d 164 (Mich. 2002) (explaining what it referred to as â€œthe transactional approachâ€ as follows:Â  â€œUnder this approach, a defendant has not completed a robbery until he has escaped with stolen merchandise.Â  Thus a completed larceny may be elevated to a robbery if the defendant uses force after the taking and before reaching temporary safety.â€).Â  
 

	American Jurisprudence elucidates:
	
		The other basic perspective is that the use of force or intimidation in retaining the property generally, or in effecting retention of the property in an escape attempt, or even merely as a means of escaping after the property has been abandoned supply the element of force or intimidation necessary to make the offense a robbery.Â  
		
	

67 Am. Jur. 2d Robbery Â§ 27 (2003) (internal footnotes omitted).
The Model Penal Code espouses the theory, focusing on whether the force or intimidation asserted against the victim is part of the entire act, and includes the use of force or intimidation to retain possession of the thing taken or to escape or prevent pursuit.Â  Model Penal Code Â§ 222.1(1) (2001). Â The code has adopted the position that a robbery occurs if the force or intimidation takes place â€œin the course of committing a theftâ€ and specifies that the commission of a theft includes the flight after the attempt or commission. Â Id.Â  Â 
The efficacy of the rule is to distinguish the perpetration of a robbery from the commission of a larceny and a subsequent assault, limiting the latter to cases where the intimidation or force is not directly related to the taking.Â  The rationale behind the differentiation of robbery and larceny buttresses the adoption of the continuous offense approach:

	[T]he purpose of the force or intimidation element of the crime of robbery is to distinguish, by imposition of a more severe penalty, those takings which pose a greater risk to the victim. The danger to the victim, however, is identical whether the force or intimidation is employed against the victim immediately before or immediately after the actual taking. We therefore conclude that the force or intimidation element of robbery is satisfied by evidence that force or intimidation directly related to the taking occurred in the course of completing the crime.

State v. Meyers, 620 So.2d 1160, 1163 (La. 1993).
In instances when a thief must use force to retain the stolen property, the thief does not acquire full possession of the property until the force or threat of force has overcome the custodianâ€™s resistance to the taking. Â See Whartonâ€™s Criminal Law Â§ 463, at 39-40 (15th ed. 1996). Â Thus, a â€œtakingâ€ is not completeâ€”that is to say, has not come to an endâ€”until the perpetrator has neutralized any immediate interference with his or her possession. Â Id. Â This does not mean, of course, that a thief has not committed a robbery or larceny unless and until resistance to his possession has been overcome. Â Indubitably, the point of asportation is not absolutely determinative.Â  A criminal is guilty of the crime, and not merely of an attempt, if he moves the stolen goods a short distance, and concomitantly, the crime is ongoing until the thief has reached a place of temporary safety.Â  See Ball v. State, 699 A.2d 1170, 1185 (Md. 1997).
An exhaustive review of the relevant authorities reveals plenitudinous jurisdictions adopting the continuous offense theory by statute.Â  See, e.g., Ala. Code Â§ 13A-8-43 (LexisNexis 2005); Alaska Stat. Â§ 11.41.510 (2006); Ariz. Rev. Stat. Ann. Â§Â§ 13-1901 to -1902 (2001); Ark. Code Ann. Â§ 5-12-102 (2005); Conn. Gen. Stat. Ann. Â§ 53a-133 (West 2001); Del. Code Ann. tit. 11, Â§ 831 (2001); Fla. Stat. Ann. Â§ 812.13 (West 2006); Haw. Rev. Stat. Ann. Â§Â§ 708-841 to -842 (LexisNexis Supp. 2006); Iowa Code Ann. Â§ 711.1 (West 2003); Ky. Rev. Stat. Ann. Â§Â§ 515.020 to .030 (LexisNexis 1999); Me. Rev. Stat. Ann. tit. 17-A, Â§ 651 (2006); Minn. Stat. Ann. Â§ 609.24 (West 2003); Mont. Code Ann. Â§ 45-5-401 (2005); Nev. Rev. Stat. Ann. Â§ 200.380 (LexisNexis 2006); N.H. Rev. Stat. Ann. Â§ 636.1 (1996); N.J. Stat. Ann. Â§ 2C:15-1 (West 2005); N.Y. Penal Law Â§ 160.00 (McKinney 1999); N.D. Cent. Code Â§ 12.1-22-01 (1997); Ohio Rev. Code Ann. Â§ 2911.02 (LexisNexis 2006); Okla. Stat. Ann. tit. 21, Â§Â§ 791 to 792 (West 2002); Or. Rev. Stat. Ann. Â§ 164.395 (West 2005); Pa. Cons. Stat. Ann. Â§ 3701 (West 2000); S.D. Codified Laws Â§Â§ 22-30-1 to -2 (LexisNexis 1998); Tex. Penal Code Ann. Â§ 29.01 to .02 (Vernon 2003); Utah Code Ann. Â§ 76-6-301 (Supp. 2006); Wash. Rev. Code Ann. Â§ 9A.56.190 (West 2000); Wyo. Stat. Ann. Â§ 6-2-401 (2005).
Multitudinous states have, by judicial fiat, embraced the theory.Â  See, eg., People v. Chamblis, 217 N.E.2d 422 (Ill. App. 1966) (â€œif a struggle immediately ensues to keep possession of the property and the thief overcomes the resistance * * * the violence is sufficient to constitute an act of robbery.â€); People v. Kennedy, 294 N.E.2d 788 (Ill. App. 1973) (â€œwhile the taking may be without force, the offense is robbery if the departure with the property is accomplished by the use of force.â€); People v. Estes, 147 Cal.App.3d 23 (1983) (â€œThe crime of robbery is a continuing offense that begins from the time of the original taking until the robber reaches a place of relative safety. Â It is sufficient to support the conviction that appellant used force to prevent the guard from retaking the property and to facilitate his escape. . . . Â Whether defendant used force to gain original possession of the property or to resist attempts to retake the stolen property, force was applied against the guard in furtherance of the robbery and can properly be used to sustain the conviction.â€); State v. Bell, 233 N.W.2d 920 (Neb. 1975) (â€œa robbery is not completed at the moment the robber obtains possession of the stolen property . . . robbery includes the element of asportation, the robberâ€™s escape with the loot being considered as important in the commission of the crime as gaining possession of the property.â€); State v. Meyers, 620 So.2d 1160, 1163 (La. 1993) (â€œthe force or intimidation element of robbery is satisfied by evidence that force or intimidation directly related to the taking occurred in the course of completing the crime.â€); Ball v. State, 699 A.2d 1170 (Md.Â  1997) (â€œThe mere fact that some asportation has occurred before the use of force does not mean that the perpetrator is thereafter not guilty of the offense of robbery. . . . Â [When] the use of force enables the accused to retain possession of the property in the face of immediate resistance from the victim, then the taking is properly considered a robbery.â€); People v. Bartowsheski, 661 P.2d 235 (Colo. 1983) (â€œThe gravamen of robbery is the application of physical force or intimidation against the victim at any time during the course of a transaction culminating in the taking of property from the victimâ€™s person or presence. Â There is no requirement that the application of force or intimidation must be virtually contemporaneous with the taking.â€); Commonwealth. v. Rajotte, 499 N.E.2d 313 (Mass. App. Ct. 1986) (â€œA larceny may be converted into a robbery if . . . an assault is committed on a person who, having some protective concern for the goods taken interferes with the completion of the theft.â€).
3. A TEMPORAL AND SPATIAL ANALYSIS OF THE EVIDENTIARY RECORD
Citing the Tennessee case of State v. Owens, 20 S.W.3d 634 (Tenn. 2000), Moore urges this court to hold that robbery requires the act of violence or intimidation â€œprecede or be concomitant to or contemporaneous with the taking of the property.â€Â  See also State v. Hope, 345 S.E.2d 361, 364 (N.C. 1986) (â€œto be found guilty of armed robbery, the defendantâ€™s use or threatened use of a dangerous weapon must precede or be concomitant with the taking, or be so joined with it in a continuous transaction by time and circumstances as to be inseparable.â€). Â Â 
A priori the reasoning and analysis in Owens is bottomed and premised upon the minority view in this country.Â  Owens plucks its rationale from a flawed and defective academic exercise.Â  The minority view does not give any credence to the criminal activity in totality.Â  Rather, the minority rule restricts and insulates the criminal activity to the zone of coinstantaneous and synchronous conduct.Â  
 
In contrariety to Mooreâ€™s contention, the crime was not â€œcompleteâ€ prior to his confrontation with Hayes.Â  Hayes confronted Moore immediately after he walked out the front doors of the store but before he left the retailerâ€™s parking lot.Â  If not for Mooreâ€™s display of a handgun, Hayes would likely have been able to thwart the thief at that time.Â  However, while still standing on Wal-Martâ€™s grounds, Moore employed the weapon to threaten Hayes with force and create fear.Â  The gun allowed Moore to actually remove the merchandise from Wal-Martâ€™s domain.Â  Perspicuously, the threat of weapon was contemporaneous to and not separable with his taking of the goods from the premises of the merchant. Â 
Simplistically put, the requisite elements of larceny are met at the point when a thief possesses an item of stolen property.Â  See State v. Keith, 283 S.C. 597, 598, 325 S.E.2d 325, 326 (1985) (â€œasportation is an element of robbery and armed robbery.â€). Â However, Mooreâ€™s crime continued as he attempted his escape through the Wal-Mart parking lot, where his threat to Hayes raised the offense from larceny to armed robbery.Â  See Burko v. State, 313 A.2d 864, 71 (Md. App. 1974) vacated on other grounds, 422 U.S. 1003, 95 S.Ct. 2624, 45 L.Ed.2d 667 (1975) (â€œwhen one commits a larceny and then displays a weapon so as to overcome the resistance of the witness, the crime is then elevated to robberyâ€) (citing Clark and Marshall, A Treatise on the Law of Crimes, Â§ 12.09 (6th ed. Wingersky rev. 1958); Perkins, Criminal Law, ch. 4, Â§ 2C at 284 (2d ed. 1969).Â  At the point he was escaping through Wal-Martâ€™s parking lot, Mooreâ€™s asportation of the stolen property was luculently within the ambit and aegis of the doctrine of asportation, an indispensable element of the offense of armed robbery.Â  The striking similitude in the factual scenario depicted in Keith as juxtaposed to this factual record brings this court to the ineluctable conclusion that Moore committed the offense of armed robbery. 
 
CONCLUSION 
We adopt the continuous offense theory based on the efficacy and rationale of the doctrine and our supreme courtâ€™s decision in State v. Keith, 283 S.C. 597, 325 S.E.2d 325 (1985).Â  Accordingly, the trial judge did not error in refusing to grant a directed verdict of acquittal.Â  Appellantâ€™s conviction for armed robbery is
AFFIRMED.
HUFF and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

title: Motley v. Williams
description: Clarence Williams appeals the denial of his motion to set aside the master-in-equityâ€™s settlement order.  We affirm.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Anthony Wade Motley, Respondent,
				v.
				Clarence Williams, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Kershaw County
Jeffrey M. Tzerman, Master-In-Equity
Opinion 4248
Submitted May 1, 2007 â€“ Filed May 18, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Stevens C. Elliott, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				George W. Speedy, of Camden, for Respondent.
			
		
	

ANDERSON, J.:Â  Â Â Clarence Williams appeals the denial of his motion to set aside the master-in-equityâ€™s settlement order.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
This action emanates from a dispute involving a 9.68 acre parcel of land in Kershaw County.Â  In 1987, Clarence Williamsâ€™ father contracted to sell the plot at issue to Anthony Motleyâ€™s father.Â  In 2002, Motley brought suit against Williams seeking transfer of the title of the subject property.[2]Â  In his complaint, Motley alleged he was entitled to relief under the theories of specific performance, part performance, and adverse possession.Â  In response, Williams raised the doctrines of statute of limitations, laches, estoppel, waiver, and innocent purchaser as defenses.Â  By consent of the parties, the matter was referred to the Kershaw County master-in-equity.Â 
 
A hearing before the master was held on June 3, 2005.Â  Although the prior communication between the lawyers and their clients is in dispute, shortly before the trial was set to convene, counsel for both sides met with the master in chambers and informed him they had reached a settlement that they desired to put on record.Â  
 
When the hearing convened, a proposed agreement was jointly presented by counsel for both parties.Â  During the hearing, the court posed questions regarding the settlement to both sidesâ€™ attorneys.Â  Motley and Williams were present throughout the entire proceeding.Â  Ultimately, the master reduced the agreement to a written order, filed on September 29, 2005.Â  
 
Subsequently, Williams retained different counsel, who moved to set aside the settlement order.Â  The master denied the motion.Â  Williams again hired a new attorney, through whom this appeal was filed. 
 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Williams contends the master erred in denying his motion to set aside the settlement order.Â  He alleges his trial attorney mistakenly entered into the agreement against his wishes and specific instructions, therefore invalidating the agreement.Â  We disagree.
1.Â  SETTLEMENT AGREEMENTS
To be enforceable, settlement agreements must either be entered into the courtâ€™s record or acknowledged in open court and placed upon the record.Â  Buckley v. Shealy, 370 S.C. 317, 322, 635 S.E.2d 76, 78 (2006); Galloway v. Regis Corp., 325 S.C. 541, 481 S.E.2d 714 (Ct. App. 1997); Kumar v. Third Generation, Inc., 324 S.C. 284, 485 S.E.2d 626 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  This requirement is provided by Rule 43(k) of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure.Â  Ashfort Corp. Palmetto Construction Group, Inc., 318 S.C. 492, 493-94, 458 S.E.2d 533, 534 (1995) (â€œIn our opinion, Rule 43(k) is applicable to settlement agreements.â€); Widewater Square Assocs. v. Opening Break of America, Inc., 319 S.C. 243, 245, 460 S.E.2d 396, (1995) (â€œa settlement order is unenforceable where it fails to set forth the terms of the settlement as required by Rule 43(k), SCRCP.â€); Reed v. Associated Invs. of Edisto Island, Inc., 339 S.C. 148, 528 S.E.2d 94 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  The rule states:

	Agreements of Counsel. No agreement between counsel affecting the proceedings in an action shall be binding unless reduced to the form of a consent order or written stipulation signed by counsel and entered in the record, or unless made in open court and noted upon the record. Â Settlement agreements shall be handled in accordance with Rule 41.1, SCRCP.

Rule 43(k), SCRCP.Â   
â€œLike former Circuit Court Rule 14 on which it is based, Rule 43(k) is intended to prevent disputes as to the existence and terms of agreements regarding pending litigation.â€Â  Ashfort at 493-94, 458 S.E.2d at 534.Â  â€œ[A]pplication of Rule 43(k) will increase the certainty of settlement agreements by avoiding disputes.Â  Id. at 494-95, 458 S.E.2d at 535.
2.Â  ATTORNEY/CLIENT CONTRACTUAL RELATIONSHIP
It is a long-standing and well-settled rule that an attorney may settle litigation on behalf of his client and that the client is bound by his attorneyâ€™s settlement actions.Â  See Crowley v. Harvey & Battey, P.A., 327 S.C. 68, 488 S.E.2d 334 (1997); Shelton v. Bressant, 312 S.C. 183, 439 S.E.2d 833, (1993); Poore v. Poore, 105 S.C. 206, 89 S.E. 569 (1915); Arnold v. Yarborough, 281 S.C. 570, 572 316 S.E.2d 416, 417 (Ct. App. 1984). Â â€œThis rule is based on the principles of agency law.â€Â  Crowley at 70, 488 S.E.2d at 335.

	It will never do, in the absence of fraud, to allow the undoubted attorneys of record for a party to a suit to enter into a solemn agreement to settle and adjust the issues and subject-matter of a suit and then later, if it is done, because for any reason the party is dissatisfied, to allow him to repudiate this agreement and employ different counsel to upset and set aside what his first counsel has done.

Poore at 211-12, 89 S.E. at 571.
â€œActs of an attorney are directly attributable to and binding upon the client.Â  Absent fraud or mistake, where attorneys of record for a party agree to settle a case, the party cannot later repudiate the agreement.â€Â  Shelton at 184, 439 S.E.2d at 834 (quoting Arnold v. Yarborough, 281 S.C. 570, 572 316 S.E.2d 416, 417 (Ct. App. 1984)).Â  This court has held:

	[E]mployment of an attorney in a particular suit implies his clientâ€™s assent that he may do everything which the court may approve in the progress of the cause. Â Upon this distinction in a large measure rest the certainty, verity, and finality of every judgment of a court. Â Litigants must necessarily be held bound by the acts of their attorneys in the conduct of a cause in court, in the absence, of course, of fraud.

Arnold at 572, 316 S.E. at 417 (quoting Ex parte Jones, 47 S.C. 393, 397, 25 S.E. 285, 286 (1896)).
Any communication failure or mistake on the part of an attorney is directly attributable to his client.Â  See Kirkland v. Moseley, 109 S.C. 477, 96 S.E. 608 (1917) (a party cannot set aside settlement agreement signed pursuant to attorneyâ€™s erroneous legal advice); see also Graham v. Town of Loris, 272 S.C. 442, 451, 248 S.E.2d 594, 598 (1978) (â€œThe general rule in this jurisdiction is that the neglect of the attorney is attributable to the client.â€).Â  Relief from such an error rests in an action against the lawyer:

	[I]f the attorney has apparent authority to confess, or consent to, judgment, it is ordinarily binding and conclusive on the client, notwithstanding an actual lack of authority unknown to the court or the opposing party, the sole remedy in such a case being against the attorney.

Lord Jeff Knitting Co., Inc. v. Mills, 281 S.C. 374, 377, 315 S.E.2d 377, 379 (Ct. App. 1984) (citing 7A C.J.S. Attorney & Client Â§ 200 at 332 (1980); Poore at 212, 89 S.E. at 569); see also Crowley at 70, 488 S.E.2d at 335 (â€œwhere a client alleges his former attorney was negligent in advising him to accept a settlement, that alleged negligence is not a ground for attacking the settlement itself but rather is a matter left for a malpractice suit between the client and his attorney.â€).
In Shelton v. Bressant, 312 S.C. 183, 439 S.E.2d 833 (1993), the appellant and his attorney appeared in open court and advised the presiding judge they had been able to settle their case with the opposing party.Â  The following day, an oral agreement between the two sides was tape-recorded and subsequently transcribed.Â  Shortly thereafter, the appellant attempted to repudiate the settlement agreement, contending it failed to meet his terms.Â  Our supreme court found the agreement binding and held:

	[Appellantsâ€™] contention that the suit was not settled according to his instructions does not entitle him to rescind the agreement.
	When a litigant voluntarily accepts an offer of settlement, either directly or indirectly through the duly authorized actions of his attorney, the integrity of the settlement cannot be attacked on the basis of inadequate representation by the litigantâ€™s attorney. Â In such cases, any remaining dispute is purely between the party and his attorney.

Id. at 185, 439 S.E.2d at 834 (citing Petty v. The Timken Corp., 849 F.2d 130, 133 (4th Cir.1988) (emphasis removed from original).
In his brief to this court, Williams asserts that he â€œrepeatedly instructed his attorney not to settle the case under any circumstances . . . .â€Â  However, during the hearing before the master, his attorney did in fact settle the case and did so directly in Williamsâ€™ presence.Â  Williams makes no claim of fraud, and offers simply that mistake existed.Â  Although he compares the issue with contract doctrine, stating â€œthere was no meeting of the minds in regard to the settlement agreement,â€ the exact cause of and parties involved in this alleged mistake are never fully articulated.Â  Williams argues: â€œ[N]o one ever explained to Mr. Williams to what he was agreeing, nor did anyone ask.Â  Because of his lack of education and experience with the court system, he was completely confused as to what was transpiring in the courtroom.â€
Undoubtedly, Williams was, or should have been, well apprised that his attorney was entering into a settlement agreement.Â  As detailed in the record:

	
		
			COURT: 
			. . . Both parties are present 
			today.  The Plaintiff is represented by George W. Speedy of the 
			Kershaw County Bar, and the Defendant is represented by Roderick M. 
			Todd of the Kershaw County.  I did briefly discuss this matter 
			with the attorneys prior to the commencement of this proceeding, and 
			I understand the parties have reached a settlement in this matter; 
			is that correct, Mr. Speedy?
 
		
		
			SPEEDY:
			That is correct, Your Honor.
 
		
		
			COURT:  
			
			If one of you would advise me of 
			what it is.
 
		
		
			SPEEDY:
			Yes, Your Honor. . . .
 
		
		
			. . .
 
			 
		
		
			SPEEDY:  
			
			And I believe that is the agreement of the parties.
 
		
		
			TODD:     
			
			Each party will be responsible for their own costs. . . . 
		
		
			COURT: 
			Did you want to question either 
			of your parties?
 
		
		
			SPEEDY: 
			I donâ€™t think thatâ€™s necessary.  
			I just wanted to put it on the record, and we are good to go.
 
		
		
			COURT:
			Okay.  Well, having heard the 
			agreement in open Court, I am glad that the parties [] were able to 
			resolve this matter between themselves privately without me having 
			to make another difficult decision as is typically the case when 
			cases make it to Court. . . .
		
	

Â As such, the transcript of the proceeding decidedly and incontestably reflects Williamsâ€™ attorneyâ€™s consent to the settlement agreement.Â  

Furthermore, the record illustrates clarity as to nature and contents of the settlement.Â  More specifically, during the hearing, the judge and two attorneys comprehensively and conspicuously laid out the manner in which the land at issue was to be divided between Motley and Williams:

	
		
			SPEEDY:
			. . . We have agreed to equally 
			divide that parcel of property, and we have agreed to divide it - - 
			how would you determine it - - - 
 
		
		
			TODD: 
			Such that Mr. Motley would 
			receive the parcel closest to land now or formerly Loblolly which 
			looks to be on the eastern side of the property.
 
		
		
			SPEEDY: 
			Thatâ€™s right.
 
		
		
			TODD:
			
			And Mr. Williams 
			would receive, of course, the other half on the western side.
 
		
		
			COURT:  
			
			And if you would, just discuss 
			for me the access road of that parcel that would be cut off for the 
			Plaintiff.
 
		
		
			SPEEDY:  
			
			It has access; thereâ€™s a deeded right-of-way across the property of Edward Evans.
		
	

Although simple, the agreement is nonetheless complete and thorough, calling for the 9.68 acre property to be divided in equal shares.Â  The arrangement clearly requires a line to be drawn from north to south through the center of the land, providing Motley with the eastern half and Williams with the remaining western portion. 
 
While Williams may at one time have had every intention of having the case tried, his attorney consented to a settlement before the court. Â His counsel presumptively possessed the authority to make such an agreement, particularly in light of the fact that Williams was present in the courtroom at that time.Â  Any mistake that may have occurred was solely a result of a communication breakdown between Williams and his attorney.Â  As prescribed by the law of this state, Williams is bound by the actions of his lawyer. Â Â Â 
Williams claims the trial court erred in not questioning the parties during the initial hearing nor requiring affidavits in deciding his motion to set aside the order.Â  He alleges the settlement agreement read into the record fails to meet the requirements of SCRCP 43(k) because it lacks the required specificity as to the terms of the agreement.Â  These issues were never raised before the master, and we therefore decline to rule on their merits, as they are not preserved for review. Â See Staubes v. City of Folly Beach, 339 S.C. 406, 412, 529 S.E.2d 543, 546 (2000) (â€œIt is well-settled that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial court to be preserved for appellate review.â€); see also Iâ€˜On, L.L.C v. Town of Mt. Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 422, 526 S.E.2d 716, 724 (2000) (â€œImposing this preservation requirement on the appellant is meant to enable the lower court to rule properly after it has considered all relevant facts, law, and arguments.â€); Ellie, Inc. v. Miccichi, 358 S.C. 78, 103, 594 S.E.2d 485, 498 (Ct. App. 2004) (â€œWithout an initial ruling by the trial court, a reviewing court simply would not be able to evaluate whether the trial court committed error.â€).
CONCLUSION 
Accordingly, the master-in-equityâ€™s ruling denying appellantâ€™s motion to set aside the settlement order is
AFFIRMED.
HUFF and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] At the time suit was brought, both Wade Motley and Willie Williams were deceased, having assigned or sold all of their rights, title and interest in the land to their sons, the named parties in this action.
