title: Patterson v. Palmetto Bank
description: Evolving from a probate action, the principal issue on appeal is whether a purchaser of a property may maintain a breach of warranty action against the sellerâ€™s estate, when the purchaser is a subsequent purchaser for value without notice and can claim paramount title to the property against the initial purchaser.
text:
In the Matter of Patterson v. Palmetto Bank


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				In the Matter of the Estate of Edward Ray Patterson, Deceased,
				
				Jody Carroll, Appellant,
				v.
				The Palmetto Bank, As Personal Representative, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal from Spartanburg County
Â J. Mark Hayes, II, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 4249
Heard April 5, 2007 â€“ Filed May 31, 2007
REVERSED AND REMANDED 
 


	
		
			
				W. Allen Reese, of Greer, for Appellant.
				Anthony H. Randall, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
			
		
	

CURETON, A.J.:Â  In this probate action, Jody Carroll appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order reversing and remanding to the probate court the issue of whether Edward Ray Patterson breached the general warranty in his deed to Carroll.Â  We reverse and remand.
FACTS
Patterson owned 1.15 acres of property (the Property) in Greenville County.Â  On May 6, 2002, he conveyed 5,128 square feet of the Property to the South Carolina Department of Transportation (SCDOT) for $12,000.Â  However, SCDOT improperly recorded the deed in Spartanburg County.Â  On March 31, 2003, Patterson conveyed the Property to Carroll by general warranty deed without mentioning the prior conveyance to SCDOT.Â 
 
Patterson died on December 6, 2003.Â  Subsequently, Carroll filed a claim against Pattersonâ€™s estate (the Estate) for monetary damages for breach of the deedâ€™s general warranty.Â  The Estate disallowed this claim, and the case was tried in the probate court.Â  At trial, the Estate argued Patterson did not breach his general warranty to Carroll because Carroll could claim paramount title against SCDOT as a subsequent purchaser for value without notice.Â  Carroll maintains he may elect to sue Patterson for breach of the warranty rather than asserting paramount title with respect to SCDOT.[1]Â   
The probate court held Patterson breached his covenant of quiet enjoyment and awarded Carroll the value of the 5,128 square feet conveyed to SCDOT.Â  The Estate appealed to the circuit court, which reversed and remanded.Â  The circuit court held the probate court properly found Carroll entitled to damages but erred in refusing to consider the priority of Carrollâ€™s title with respect to SCDOT.Â  For this reason, the circuit court held, sua sponte, that SCDOT was an indispensable party and should be joined on remand.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
An action for the breach of a deed warranty is one at law.Â  Welsh v. Davis, 37 S.C. 215 (1872).Â  On appeal from an action at law, the circuit court and the appellate court may not disturb the probate courtâ€™s findings of fact unless a review of the record discloses that no evidence supports them.Â  Neely v. Thomasson, 365 S.C. 345, 349-50, 618 S.E.2d 884, 886 (2005). Questions of law may, however, be decided by this court without deference to the lower court. Â Mariarty v. Garden Sanctuary Church of God, 341 S.C. 320, 327, 534 S.E.2d 672, 675 (2000).Â Â  Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Carroll contends the circuit court erred in refusing to hold he may maintain his breach of deed warranty action against the Estate despite his ability to assert a claim of paramount title against SCDOT.Â  Because Patterson breached the covenant of seisin in his deed to Carroll, we agree.
Preliminarily, we note the probate court technically erred in finding Patterson breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment contained in the deed to Carroll.Â  However, the probate courtâ€™s ruling is substantively correct because Patterson breached the deedâ€™s covenant of seisin.Â  In addition, the issue tried by the parties was whether Patterson breached the general warranty in the deed.Â  Accordingly, we hold the probate courtâ€™s error did not prejudice either party and forms no basis for reversal.
In Bennett v. Investors Title Ins. Co., 370 S.C. 578, 592, 635 S.E.2d 649, 656 (Ct. App. 2006), this court explained:

	A South Carolina general warranty deed embraces all of the following five covenants usually inserted in fee simple conveyances by English conveyors: (1) that the seller is seized in fee; (2) that he has a right to convey; (3) that the purchaser, his heirs and assigns, shall quietly enjoy the land; (4) that the land is free from all encumbrances; and (5) for further assurances.

(quoting Martin v. Floyd, 282 S.C. 47, 51, 317 S.E.2d 133, 136 (Ct. App. 1984)).
The covenant of seisin is the grantorâ€™s covenant that he owns title to the property being conveyed.Â  See Johnson v. Veal, 14 S.C.L. (3 McCord) 449, 450 (Ct. App. 1826) (â€œ[I]t has been held that under a general warranty of title the purchaser may maintain an action against the grantor before eviction if he can shew [sic] that he had no title at the time of sale.â€); 21 C.J.S. Covenants Â§ 16 (2006) (â€œThe covenant of seisin is the grantorâ€™s promise that he or she owns the property interest he or she purports to convey to the grantee.â€); 20 Am.Jur.2d Covenants, Conditions, and Restrictions Â§ 82 (2005) (â€œThe covenant of seisin is a promise that the grantor has good title to the estate which he or she is purporting to convey.â€).Â 
 
On the other hand, â€œ[t]he covenant of quiet enjoyment obligates the grantor to protect the estate against the lawful claim of ownership asserted by a third person.â€Â  Martin, 282 S.C. at 51, 317 S.E.2d at 136.Â  However, â€œ[n]o breach of this covenant occurs until there has been a disturbance of possession by actual or constructive eviction.â€ Â Id. at 51, 317 S.E.2d at 136.Â  
 
In this case, the probate court held Patterson breached his covenant of quiet enjoyment, but the Estate correctly recognizes Carroll has not been evicted because he voluntarily surrendered his right to claim title against SCDOT.Â  See 21 C.J.S. Covenants (2006) (â€œEven if there has been a claim of title asserted by a third party and the grantee surrendered title because of it, that will not establish a breach of covenants in a warranty deed unless the third party actually holds superior title.â€). Accordingly, the probate court erred in finding Patterson breached his covenant of quiet enjoyment.
However, the probate courtâ€™s substantive ruling is correct because Patterson breached his covenant of seisin at the time he conveyed the Property to Carroll.Â  Moreover, the Estate is not prejudiced by the technical error because the parties litigated the issue of whether Patterson breached the covenant of seisin.Â  Carrollâ€™s claim against the Estate generally alleged a breach of deed warranty and did not specify that only the covenant of quiet enjoyment had been breached.Â 
 
While Carroll failed to specify the breach as a breach of the covenant of seisin, we recognize â€œ[a] party need not use the exact name of a legal doctrine in order to preserve it . . .â€Â  State v. Dunbar  356 S.C. 138, 142, 587 S.E.2d 691, 694 (2003).Â  Further, the Estateâ€™s appeal to the circuit court merely alleged error in the probate courtâ€™s general ruling that Patterson breached the deed warranty.Â  
 
Having determined Patterson breached his covenant of seisin, we proceed to the issue of whether Carroll could elect to claim damages for that breach rather than instituting an action claiming superior title to the tract against SCDOT.Â  We hold the circuit court erred in ruling Carroll could not litigate his claim against the Estate rather than attempting to assert paramount title against SCDOT.Â 
 
A breach of the covenant of seisin arises at the time of the conveyance and supports an action against the grantor prior to actual or constructive eviction.Â  See Lessly v. Bowie, 27 S.C. 193, 198, 3 S.E. 199, 201 (1887) (recognizing the breach of a covenant that the vendor is seized in fee â€œwas as old as the deed itself, and as it has been held, would have supported an original action at law for damages, even before eviction.â€); 14 Powell on Real Property Â§ 81A.06[2][a][iv] (2005) (â€œ[The covenant of seisin] is broken, if at all, at the time of the conveyance . . . . It is not necessary that the grantee actually be evicted from the premises in order for the cause of action to accrue.â€).Â  Consequently, Carroll had the ability to file suit on the breach at the time Patterson delivered the deed without regard to whether Carroll was evicted or could be evicted.
Here, the circuit courtâ€™s order presupposes that the probate court must make a finding of eviction before allowing Carroll to proceed with his claim against the Estate.Â  However, as we have explained, Pattersonâ€™s covenant of seisin was breached when he conveyed the Property to Carroll regardless of whether an eviction occurred.Â  Accordingly, the circuit courtâ€™s decision is reversed and remanded for entry of an order consistent herewith.
REVERSED AND REMANDED.[2]
 
BEATTY, J., and WILLIAMS, J., concur.Â  

[1] Carroll testified at trial that he acquiesced to SCDOTâ€™s ownership of the area it claimed. Moreover, at oral argument before this court, Carrollâ€™s counsel waived any right he may have to pursue a claim against SCDOT.
[2] Based on this decision, we need not address Carrollâ€™s other issues on appeal.Â  See Rule 220(c), SCACR (â€œThe appellate court may affirm any ruling, order, decision or judgment upon any ground(s) appearing in the Record on Appealâ€); Hagood v. Sommerville, 362 S.C. 191, 199, 607 S.E.2d 707, 711 (2005) (recognizing appellate courts need not address the remaining issues when one issue is dispositive).

State v. Willard

<!--

-->



THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Joshua Willard, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Union County
John C. Hayes, III, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 4250
Heard April 10, 2007 â€“ Filed May 31, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Appellate Defender Aileen P. Clare, of Columbia, for Appellant.Â  
				
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, 
				Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy 
				Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Senior Assistant 
				Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., all of Columbia; and 
				Solicitor Thomas E. Pope, of York, for Respondent.
			
		
	

STILWELL, J.: Â Joshua Willard appeals his conviction for trafficking methamphetamine.Â  We affirm.Â  
FACTS
William Eugene Adams (Informant) was arrested on a family court bench warrant and found with a quantity of methamphetamine. Â Officer Kevin Smith notified Officer John Sherfield, a narcotics officer.Â  Sherfield went to the jail and met with Informant.Â  Informant told Officer Sherfield he and Joshua Willard were related, that Informant had purchased drugs from Willard in the past, and he intended to purchase drugs from Willard that day.Â  Informant agreed to set up the buy and Officer Sherfield agreed to â€œtry to helpâ€ Informant on his drug charge in exchange for his cooperation.Â  Informant and Willard had not set a meeting place for the buy and Officer Sherfield directed Informant to arrange for the meeting to take place at a local movie theater parking lot. Â 
Using Sherfieldâ€™s mobile telephone, Informant called Willard.Â  A transcription of the conversation was introduced into evidence:

	
		
			Willard:
			Hello.
 
		
		
			Informant:
			Hey.
 
		
		
			Willard:
			Yo.
 
		
		
			Informant: 
			
			Whatâ€™s up man?
 
		
		
			Willard: 
			
			Whatâ€™s up?
 
		
		
			Informant: 
			
			. . . I dunno, Iâ€™m trying to figure that out with you man . . . <unclear> . . . Iâ€™ve been shooting smooth, just wanna know where you at, where I need to be[.]
 
		
		
			Willard:
			Iâ€™ve been <unclear>
 
		
		
			Informant: 
			
			You canâ€™t come to Union man?
 
		
		
			Willard:
			Yeah I can come to Union.
 
		
		
			Informant:
			Alright.
 
		
		
			Willard: 
			
			Hey, where you gonna be at?
 
		
		
			Informant:Â 
			Uhhhhh come to the movie theater parking lot man. Â <garbled noise>
 
		
		
			Willard: 
			
			 . . . <unclear> . . . come 
			see you.
 
		
		
			Informant: 
			
			What you mean the house or something?
 
		
		
			Willard:
			Yeah I mean Iâ€™m getting ready to 
			meet up with somebody and itâ€™s gonna take a . . . <unclear> . . .
 
		
		
			Informant:
			Okay.
 
		
		
			Willard:
			. . . Iâ€™m in Union already.
 
		
		
			Informant:
			Just meet me at the movie 
			theater at the same time.
 
		
		
			Willard: 
			
			Alright.
 
		
		
			Informant:
			Alright.
		
	

Sherfield testified the phrase â€œshooting smoothâ€ meant smoking methamphetamine.Â  Sherfield had no previous experience with Informant but testified Informant accurately described Willardâ€™s black Honda Civic that had dark tinted windows.Â  Sherfield also claimed Willard had been identified as being involved in drug transactions with methamphetamine by other informants in the past, although he had never been arrested.Â  
The telephone call on Sherfieldâ€™s mobile phone to Willard originated at the car dock area of the Union County jail. Â Sherfield admitted there was a magistrate on duty at the courthouse in the same location at the time.Â  However, Sherfield believed he had reasonable suspicion to search Willardâ€™s car and question him without a warrant from the magistrate. Â 
Later that day, Officer Kitchens radioed Sherfield and told him he had spotted Willard within a half mile of the movie theater.Â  Sherfieldâ€™s mobile phone rang, reporting a call from the number Informant called earlier.Â  Sherfield did not answer.Â  Constable Billy Bennett arrived at the theater in a green pickup truck.Â  Kitchens was in the parking lot and watched Willard drive into the parking lot.Â  Officer Smith also pulled into the parking lot. Â Sherfield pulled in and the four officers converged on Willardâ€™s car, blocking it in.Â  Informant was not present, as he had already been booked and incarcerated. Â 
Kitchens testified he asked Willard and the other occupant of his vehicle, a male, to exit the car.Â  After the men exited the car, Sherfield explained their rights to them.Â  Sherfield asked Willard â€œwhere the drugs were.â€Â  Willard denied any knowledge of drugs.Â  Sherfield held up his mobile phone and said â€œyou (sic) been calling my phone.â€Â  Willard â€œdropped his head and said theyâ€™re in the console . . . .â€Â  Kitchens approached the vehicle and found 17.46 grams of methamphetamine, digital scales, and $1,012 in cash.Â  
At trial, the court heard pre-trial motions, including Willardâ€™s motion to suppress the drugs.Â  Officers Sherfield and Kitchens testified.Â  The court denied the motion finding, inter alia, Willard consented to the search.Â  
Standard of Review

    In criminal cases, an appellate court sits to review errors of law only. Therefore, an appellate court is bound by the trial courtâ€™s factual findings unless they are clearly erroneous.Â  State v. Baccus, 367 S.C. 41, 48, 625 S.E.2d 216, 220 (2006).Â  The same standard of review applies to preliminary factual findings in determining the admissibility of certain evidence in criminal cases.Â  State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 5-6, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001).Â  Our review in Fourth Amendment search and seizure cases is limited to determining whether any evidence supports the trial courtâ€™s finding.Â  State v. Butler, 353 S.C. 383, 388, 577 S.E.2d 498, 500-01 (Ct. App. 2003).
DISCUSSION
Willard argues the trial judge erred in denying his motion to suppress the drugs as the product of an unlawful search.Â  We disagree.
The Fourth Amendment guarantees â€œ[t]he right of the people to be secure . . . [from] unreasonable searches and seizures.â€Â  U.S. Const. amend. IV.Â  A warrantless search generally offends the Fourth Amendment.Â  State v. Dupree, 319 S.C. 454, 456, 462 S.E.2d 279, 281 (1995).Â  A warrantless search withstands constitutional scrutiny under the Fourth Amendment if it meets the requirements of one of several exceptions, including the automobile exception.Â  Id.Â  â€œAs a general matter, the decision to stop an automobile is reasonable where the police have probable cause to believe that a traffic violation has occurred.Â  The police, however, may also stop and briefly detain a vehicle if they have a reasonable suspicion that the occupants are involved in criminal activity.â€Â  State v. Butler, 343 S.C. 198, 201, 539 S.E.2d 414, 416 (Ct. App. 2000) (internal citations omitted).
â€œâ€˜Reasonable suspicionâ€™ requires a â€˜particularized and objective basis that would lead one to suspect another of criminal activity.â€™â€Â  State v. Khingratsaiphon, 352 S.C. 62, 69, 572 S.E.2d 456, 459 (2002) (quoting United States v. Cortez, 449 U.S. 411, 418 (1981)).Â  In determining whether reasonable suspicion exists, the court must consider the totality of the circumstances.Â  State v. Rogers, 368 S.C. 529, 534, 629 S.E.2d 679, 682 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  Reasonable suspicion is more than a general hunch but less than what is required for probable cause.Â  Butler, 343 S.C. at 202, 539 S.E.2d at 416.
In State v. Green, this court held an anonymous telephone tip provided insufficient indicia of reliability to justify an investigatory stop.Â  341 S.C. 214, 218, 532 S.E.2d 896, 897 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  However, in State v. Rogers, this court found a stop based on a known, reliable, confidential informant sufficient to meet the reasonable suspicion standard.Â  368 S.C. at 535, 629 S.E.2d at 682.Â  We find this case meets the criteria of Rogers.Â  Although the informant in this case was not previously proven reliable, as in Rogers, he was more than a mere tipster.Â  The informant correctly identified Willardâ€™s vehicle, knew Willardâ€™s telephone number, and mentioned drugs during the conversation with Willard.Â  Although the informantâ€™s reliability had not previously been tested, a non-confidential informant is given a higher level of credibility because he exposes himself to liability should the information prove to be false.Â  See State v. Bellamy, 323 S.C. 199, 204, 473 S.E.2d 838, 841 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  We thus find support to affirm the trial courtâ€™s finding of reasonable suspicion for the stop.Â  
We likewise find the requisite exigent circumstances for a warrantless search, arising from mobility, as required under California v. Carney, 471 U.S. 386 (1985).Â  In Carney, the court upheld the warrantless search of a lawfully parked but fully mobile motor home under the automobile exception.Â  471 U.S. at 395.Â  Willard argues because the officers surrounded his vehicle, it was not â€œmobileâ€ under Carney.Â  However, temporary immobility may still be considered readily mobile so as to qualify for the automobile exception.Â  See Myers v. State, 839 N.E.2d 1146, 1152 (Ind. 2005) (cases cited therein).
In any event, we find Willard voluntarily consented to the search.[1]Â  â€œWarrantless searches and seizures are reasonable within the meaning of the Fourth Amendment when conducted under the authority of voluntary consent.â€Â  Palacio v. State, 333 S.C. 506, 514, 511 S.E.2d 62, 66 (1999).Â  â€œUndoubtedly, a law enforcement officer may request permission to search at any time. Â However, when an officer asks for consent to search after an unconstitutional detention, the consent procured is per se invalid unless it is both voluntary and not an exploitation of the unlawful detention.â€Â  State v. Pichardo, 367 S.C. 84, 105, 623 S.E.2d 840, 851 (Ct. App. 2005) (emphasis in original).Â  Whether consent to a search is voluntary is a question of fact to be determined from the totality of the circumstances.Â  State v. McKnight, 352 S.C. 635, 656, 576 S.E.2d 168, 179 (2003).Â  
We find evidence to support the trial courtâ€™s finding that the consent was voluntary.Â  Willardâ€™s consent to search was obtained after Officer Sherfield read Willard his rights under Miranda v. Arizona, 384 U.S. 436 (1966).Â  Willard consented to the search by nodding his head toward the vehicle and telling the officers the drugs were in the console, after notification of the calls to Sherfieldâ€™s mobile phone.Â  
We likewise find the search was not an exploitation of an unlawful detention.Â  As previously discussed, we find reasonable suspicion existed to make the stop and detention.Â  Furthermore, although Willard allegedly noticed the officersâ€™ guns when first surrounded, there is no evidence of any threat of force against Willard once he had exited his vehicle.Â  Nor is there evidence of coercion or promises made.Â  After review of all the circumstances, we find no error by the trial court in denying Willardâ€™s motion to suppress the drugs.Â  See Green, 341 S.C. at 219 n.3, 532 S.E.2d at 898 n.3Â  (holding â€œthe appellate standard of review in Fourth Amendment search and seizure cases is limited to determining whether any evidence supports the trial courtâ€™s finding and the appellate court may only reverse where there is clear error.â€).
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and GOOLSBY, J., concur.

[1] Although the State argues this issue is not preserved for appellate review as not raised on appeal, we find sufficient argument in Willardâ€™s brief to address the issue.
